story:
Our mission is to provide opportunities to children in Latin America through education in Computer Science and Olympic sport values

In February of 2015, the Roberto Carcelen Foundation opened the doors of a new educational laboratory in Lima, Peru. The lab’s focus is to provide the children of Lima with a place where they can acquire the tools they need to build a brighter future.

Currently our educational lab focuses on programs associated with computer science, English language proficiency, leadership values and life lessons learned though the practice of athletics. We believe that investing in the lives of these children will ensure that we are helping to create a positive future for Latin America.

  • We provide free education on computer science. Our students learn how to code and getting their hands on real projects. Our group of developer trainers involve the students on practical problem solving projects through programming.
  • Our children are learning English as well! We have two great English native speakers that provide English lessons.
  • We not only provide a technical curriculum in coding but we also assist with providing nourishment by ways of a warm daily breakfast
  • We provide work opportunities for the older teenagers to join the workforce as a web developer.
  • Our U.S and Peru based mentors are leaders, CEO's, athletes that connect with our students via Skype twice a month to demonstrate the children that anything is possible and we all care about them. 
  • This is where our children will be working when finishing our program. Where our students will have the opportunity to provide (paid) services, but also provide company culture and values that make great companies thrive.

Why We Need Your Support?

  • Our 2016 program starts on September 2016. 31 Students have signed up and another 48 are in waiting list. We have opened an afternoon shift to serve those kids that work in the mornings. We are forecasting 100+ graduates by the end of the 2016 calendar year and our goal is to have 70% of them joining the workforce throughout 2016 and 2017 as web developers !
  • Keep in mind that $297 funds our computer science program (read more below) per student for a full year! This is $25 at month/per student!

Who Do We Help?

Since the start of the year, 90 children have been enrolled in our free education programs.

  • 70% are girls.
  • They come from extreme poor areas (Cantagallo and others nearby)
  • Our first group graduated last September, 60% of them are now working for companies engaged with our mission. They are now bringing revenue to their household empowering and helping their overall realities.

Our Education Programs

  • Code to Work: Serves teenagers that have already finished school and are in need of skills to join the work force. Their ages range from 15 to 22 years old.
    • Skills: Front end and Backend programming backed by world class curriculum provided by Udemy.
    • Duration: 6 months/ daily

  • Play to grow: Serves children that are currently attending school or work in the morning. Ages ranging from 8 to 15 years old.
    • Skills: Introduction to technology by developing their own games, using Scratch, Robotzzle, Minecraft.
    • Duration: 6 months/ weekends

Outreach Programs

  • Mobile Lab: We bring our education to children located in remote areas of Lima. 

  • Workshops: Technology and native language preservation. Most our students migrated from remote rural areas, their primary language is not Spanish. We partnered with The Idea Agency and the Office of human inclusion of Ministry of Culture to bring awareness and practice to the importance of preserving their own identity. As a result, our children are now coding and developing in their own native languages in addition to Spanish. 

  • Outreach: Bringing Code.org program 'Hour of Code' to schools and recreational events.

  • Events: We partnered with Microsoft Peru to bring Developer Days. Our students got to interact with other techies, attended seminars and presented their prototypes.

The Challenging Context

In Latin American countries, the vast majority of children in relative poverty also suffer from extreme degrees of absolute deprivation, making the challenge of child poverty all the more urgent. In fact, in all but three countries (Chile, Costa Rica and Uruguay), over half of all children below the relative poverty line live in families which do not have sufficient income for a proper diet.

·  Latin America has the world's highest levels of social inequality

·  91% of Children in poverty in Peru do not have access to a college education.

·  Fewer than half the girls in the developing world will never reach secondary school.

Barriers

  • Recruiting

o People from these communities are resistant and doubtful about accepting help. We had to find a way to break through this barrier.

o  We decided to do onsite recruiting, Roberto Carcelen along with the team visited Cantagallo community and went door to door explaining the education opportunity and how it could break that multi-generational poverty cycle. It took time to gain their trust, but in the end it worked out, (certainly Roberto being an Olympic athlete helped). Our first group of graduates from Cantagallo was the best proof for them that our program works.

 Door to door

  Our graduates helping with recruiting

  • Lack of food:

o  We experienced high drop out and class absence rates. After further investigation we found out lack of food was the reason. Students aimed their efforts to find breakfast instead of coming to class.

o  We decided to provide a well-balanced breakfast to sustain their morning studies. Since then, the dropout & absence rates is now zero!

  • Violence at home:

o  Children that come to the academy are shy by nature and hard to express their feelings and problems that affect them.

With the help if our psychologists, staff members and instructors we were able to cracked that barrier and understand that high number of these students live in violent homes and are often too frightened and embarrassed to speak out.

We identified this as critical point that needed attention in order to stabilize emotionally these children, overcoming that hurdle has helped our children to be more open and willing to learn new skills. Our Psychologists have been supporting these students through 1:1 therapy that also involves their parents. 

How Does the Money Work?

We have super low administrative costs as we run a solid volunteer program through our corporate environment network. 

Our self-sustain model: 

  •  The RCF will fund 100% of setup and operations for their academies for the first year
  • 50% for the first 6 months of the following year and then each academy will fly on its own by a self-sustain/ blue print program
  • The self-sustain will be possible by creating partnerships with local corporations, sponsorship programs and fees from job placements.
  • Consulting services fees.
  • Applying to local and international grants
  • Local Fundraisers and crowdfunding 

Plans to Grow?

Yes! We are opening RCF Academy in Quito Ecuador, March 2017

About Roberto Carcelen

At the age of 36, in the mountains of the Pacific Northwest, Roberto Carcelen learned how to ski for the first time. Only 3 years later, Roberto traveled to Vancouver British Columbia to represent Peru as their first cross country skier and Winter Olympian. In 2014 Roberto would travel to Sochi Russia and compete a second time for his homeland of Peru. On his journey he would face many challenges and struggles. These times of strife would teach Roberto to embrace the values of perseverance, determination, and tenacity. These core values were the source of his success and enabled Roberto to reach goals that most would find unachievable.

“Will this journey of adversity and pain have a purpose? How can I turn my struggles, doubts, failures, and victories along this Olympic voyage into story of hope and perseverance for the people of my region?” These were the thoughts that consumed my mind as I struggled through debilitating pain crossing the finish line at the 2014 Sochi Olympics.

The Roberto Carcelen Foundation was established in Seattle, Washington in May 2014.
story_txt:
Our
mission is to provide opportunities to children in Latin America through
education in Computer Science and Olympic sport values
In February of 2015, the Roberto
Carcelen Foundation opened the doors of a new educational laboratory in Lima,
Peru. The lab’s focus is to provide the children of Lima with a place where
they can acquire the tools they need to build a brighter future.
Currently our educational lab
focuses on programs associated with computer science, English language
proficiency, leadership values and life lessons learned though the practice of
athletics. We believe that investing in the lives of these children will ensure
that we are helping to create a positive future for Latin America.


We provide
free education on computer science.
     Our students learn how to code and getting their hands on real projects.
     Our group of developer trainers involve the students on practical problem
     solving projects through programming.

Our children are learning English as well! We have two great English native speakers that provide
     English lessons.
We
     not only provide a technical curriculum in coding but we also assist with providing nourishment by ways of a
     warm daily breakfast


We provide
work opportunities for the older
     teenagers to join the workforce as a web developer.

Our U.S and Peru based mentors are leaders, CEO's,
     athletes that connect with our students
     via Skype twice a month to demonstrate the children that anything is
     possible and we all care about them. 
This
     is where our children will be working when finishing our program. Where
     our students will have the
     opportunity to provide (paid) services, but also provide company
     culture and values that make great companies thrive.

Why We Need Your Support?

Our 2016 program starts on September 2016. 31 Students have signed up and another 48 are in waiting list. We have opened an afternoon shift to serve those kids that work in the mornings. We are forecasting 100+ graduates by the end of the 2016 calendar year and our goal is to have 70% of them joining the workforce throughout 2016 and 2017 as web developers !
Keep in mind that $297 funds our computer science program (read more below) per student for a full year! This is
$25 at month/per student!

Who Do We Help?
Since the start of the year, 90
children have been enrolled in our free education programs.

70% are girls.
They come from extreme poor areas (Cantagallo and
     others nearby)
Our first group graduated last September, 60% of them
     are now working for companies engaged with our mission. They are now
     bringing revenue to their household empowering and helping their overall
     realities.



Our Education Programs


Code
     to Work: Serves teenagers that have already finished
     school and are in need of skills to join the work force. Their ages range
     from 15 to 22 years old.


Skills:
      Front end and Backend programming backed by world class curriculum
      provided by Udemy.

Duration:
      6 months/ daily






Play
     to grow: Serves children that are currently attending school or
     work in the morning. Ages ranging from 8 to 15 years old.


Skills:
      Introduction to technology by developing their own games, using
      Scratch, Robotzzle, Minecraft.

Duration: 6
      months/ weekends






Outreach Programs

Mobile Lab: We bring our education to children
located in remote areas of Lima. 



Workshops: Technology and native language preservation. Most our
students migrated from remote rural areas, their primary language is not Spanish. We
partnered with The Idea Agency and the Office of human inclusion of Ministry of
Culture to bring awareness and practice to the importance of preserving
their own identity. As a result, our children are now coding and developing in
their own native languages in addition to Spanish. 


Outreach: Bringing Code.org program 'Hour of Code' to schools and
recreational events.



Events: We partnered with Microsoft Peru to bring Developer Days.
Our students got to interact with other techies, attended seminars and
presented their prototypes. 

The
Challenging Context
In Latin American countries, the
vast majority of children in relative poverty also suffer from extreme degrees
of absolute deprivation, making the challenge of child poverty all the more
urgent. In fact, in all but three countries (Chile, Costa Rica and Uruguay),
over half of all children below the relative poverty line live in families
which do not have sufficient income for a proper diet.
· 
Latin America has the world's
highest levels of social inequality 
· 
91% of Children in poverty in Peru
do not have access to a college education.
· 
Fewer than half the girls in the
developing world will never reach secondary school.
Barriers
Recruitingo People from these communities are resistant and doubtful about accepting help. We had to find a way to break through this barrier.o  We decided to do onsite recruiting, Roberto Carcelen along with the team visited Cantagallo community and went door to door explaining the education opportunity and how it could break that multi-generational poverty cycle. It took time to gain their trust, but in the end it worked out, (certainly Roberto being an Olympic athlete helped). Our first group of graduates from Cantagallo was the best proof for them that our program works.

 Door
to door

 
Our graduates helping with recruiting 


Lack of
food:

o 
We experienced high
drop out and class absence rates. After further investigation we found out
lack of food was the reason. Students aimed their efforts to find breakfast
instead of coming to class. 
o 
We decided to provide a
well-balanced breakfast to sustain their morning studies. Since then, the
dropout & absence rates is now zero!


Violence at
home:

o 
Children that come to the academy
are shy by nature and hard to express their feelings and problems that affect
them. 
With the help if our psychologists,
staff members and instructors we were able to cracked that barrier
and understand that high number of these students live in violent homes
and are often too frightened and embarrassed to speak out.
We identified this as critical point
that needed attention in order to stabilize emotionally these children,
overcoming that hurdle has helped our children to be more open and willing to
learn new skills. Our Psychologists have been supporting these students through
1:1 therapy that also involves their parents. 
How Does the Money Work?
We have super low administrative
costs as we run a solid volunteer program through our corporate environment
network.  Our self-sustain model: 

 The
RCF will fund 100% of setup
and operations for their academies for the first year
50% for the first 6 months of the
following year and then each academy will fly on its own by a self-sustain/ blue print program
The self-sustain will be possible
by creating partnerships with local corporations, sponsorship programs
and fees from job placements.
Consulting services fees.
Applying to local and
international grants
Local Fundraisers and
crowdfunding 

Plans to Grow?
Yes! We are opening RCF Academy in
Quito Ecuador, March 2017About Roberto Carcelen
At the age of 36, in the mountains of the Pacific Northwest, Roberto Carcelen
learned how to ski for the first time. Only 3 years later, Roberto traveled to
Vancouver British Columbia to represent Peru as their first cross country
skier and Winter Olympian.  In 2014 Roberto would travel to Sochi Russia
and compete a second time for his homeland of Peru.  On his journey he
would face many challenges and struggles.  These times of strife would teach
Roberto to embrace the values of perseverance, determination, and tenacity.
These core values were the source of his success and enabled Roberto to
reach goals that most would find unachievable.“Will this journey of adversity and pain have a purpose?  How can I turn my
struggles, doubts, failures, and victories along this Olympic voyage into story
of hope and perseverance for the people of my region?”  These were the
thoughts that consumed my mind as I struggled through debilitating pain
crossing the finish line at the 2014 Sochi Olympics.The Roberto Carcelen Foundation was established in Seattle, Washington in
May 2014.

story:
Konyango Community Based Organization (KCBO) was founded in 2012 to help the village of Konyango Mboto, Kenya successfully adjust to the social, political and economic challenges of modernization. The community identified education as key to overcoming these challenges, and constructed its first school, Mboto Sunrise primary school.

The education a child receives from ages 0-8 is critical and influences the child for life. However in Konyango, Kenya, approximately 90% of early childhood teachers are not trained and are therefore unable to help the children develop to full learning capacity. In 2013, we initiated a six-week early childhood teacher capacity strengthening training program: the Weekend Teacher Training program (WTT). WTT takes place for six Saturdays in July and August, followed by eight months of the Early Childhood Development and Education (ECDE) innovation challenge through a K-Club Initiative. The K-Club Initiative encourage teachers to apply the skills they acquired in WTT to the classroom over the upcoming school year.

In the past two years, we have conducted trainings on professional records and child development. In 2014, due to overwhelming demand, the program expanded to included 15 schools in Osiri sub-location. In 2015, the training theme is "Teaching Without a Book and a Pen" and will focus on the role of play as a teaching strategy especially in teaching the core activity areas:

  • Language
  • Mathematics
  • Outdoor activities

Here's where YOU come in:

We've scaled up significantly since our first WTT back in 2013, and we need your help to provide books, teaching materials... for our teachers. 

100% of your generous contributions to our campaign will go directly to:

  • Development and production of 40 course packets
  • Course facilitation fees
  • Acquisition of other course materials and equipment such as course texts, portable projector and projection screen
  • 500 warm meals for 40 teachers over 6 weekends
  • Course impact monitoring and evaluation over 8 months....

__________

"Encouraging children to play and explore helps them learn and develop socially, emotionally, physically and intellectually."-www.unicef.org/earlychildhood

Help us raise $5,800 by Summer 2015 to enable 40 teachers to participate in the 2015 Weekend Teacher Training Program! Visit us at  http://konyangocbo.org


Email: konyangocbo@gmail.com for further inquiry.


Asante Sana! (Swahili for thank you)

story:
Let’s educate 50 future Greek tech leaders to help fight 50% Greek youth unemployment.

Right now, almost 50% of Greeks under the age of 25 are unemployed. At the same time, almost one million new jobs in IT will be created in Europe in 2015. We at CareerFoundry want to help young Greeks get the skills they need so they can land these in-demand jobs and build some financial freedom.

At CareerFoundry, we believe strongly that education is the number one way to achieve future prosperity. Every day, we help folks with little or no tech experience get the skills, thinking, and portfolio required by today’s top companies in 3 to 6 months. We believe the future of Greece--and Europe--depends on empowering young people to build their own road to financial freedom.

Your donation will help fund the training of 50 young Greeks to be web developers and UX designers. Once these men and women complete the program, they’ll be able to jumpstart their career, find jobs, become freelancers and build their own businesses. With your donation, you join us in sending the young men and women of Greece a message of hope.

What We Need 

We have already set aside a scholarship fund that can sponsor 10 Greek students on our Web Development and UX Design program.  In order to make an even greater impact, we would like to offer 40 more young Greek women and men the chance to study with us at no cost. To do this, we need your help to fundraise an additional €32.000 to cover the minimum online mentors and operational costs to provide another 40 online mentored tech courses for free to Greek nationals.

For these 40 places we will offset 50% of the cost of the course, and the remaining 50% we hope to raise through donations on this page, to cover the minimum mentor and operational costs. CareerFoundry will not make any profit and we will contribute a lot of resources to make this happen.

If we don’t raise all the money, we will still use the available funds to offer a scholarship to as many students as possible. 

The Impact

Your donation will help us train your Greeks in tech skills so they can launch their new careers. This will help them become financially independent. And since many tech jobs can be done remotely, their money stays in Greece, further reviving the Greek economy. In time, we hope these folks will start their own businesses, and attract more talent and money to Greece. In the long run, this will make Greece financially secure so they can rely less on banks and become a more solvent state.

Donate now to educate 50 Greek Tech Leaders!

Join us in our mission to help young Greek women and men get out of the crisis. Please donate whatever you can to this Indiegogo page--even the price of a coffee could help.

Greek Tech Scholarship Applicants

If you are a Greek national and would like to apply for our scholarship, simply click the link below, fill out your details, and let us know why you think you are eligible to receive it. We are excited to hear from people with big ideas on what they will do with their new skills, be that go freelance, set up your own company or start applying for jobs.

http://careerfoundry.com/greek-tech-leaders-scholarship

*Our Greek Tech Leaders Scholarship will be launching on 15th July 2015.

Other ways you can help

We understand that not everyone can contribute--but that doesn’t mean you can’t help. We appreciate all efforts to help us get the word out about the fund. Feel free to share with your friends and family. To make it easier, feel free to use the indiegogo sharing buttons.

CareerFoundry: online mentored tech education

CareerFoundry teaches vocational tech skills in Web Development and UX Design. We take complete beginners and bring them up to employable standards in technology through our mentored, online courseware. Students can study anywhere and at their own pace with their mentor always on hand to help.

story:
Short Summary

Hi! I'm Edoardo and about 4 years ago I have founded the International Security Observer - ISO (http://securityobserver.org/), a web-magazine for young professionals in foreign affairs. Since then, ISO has sought to foster the next generation of security experts by encouraging discussion on strategic issues among peers. 
Our next step is to establish ISO as a non-profit organization, providing training activities to recent graduates and young professionals wanting to build a career in the security sector. 
Through this crowdfunding campaign, you will help us to:  
  • Setting up our first office in Brussels. Depending on the budget, we plan on extending our activities in Washington DC and, if possible, elsewhere;
  • Carrying out training activities to help young professionals in the early stage of their careers acquiring practical skills;
  • Help students and young professionals finding paid internships and job opportunities;
  • Sustaining our website and editorial activities;

What We Need & What You Get

We are seeking to raise at least 300.000 €.

This money will be used for:

  1. Rent an office in Brussels (and possibly in Washington DC) = 80/ 100.000 € / year
  2. Employ 3 full time staff employees = 100.000 € / year 
  3. Organize training activities on practical skills (e.g. Trend / Scenario analysis, Open Source Intelligence, Big Data and predictive analytics, etc.) = 80.000 € / year
  4. Fund for post-training paid internships in public and private organizations = 20-30.000 € / year

The Impact

Our mission is to fill the gap between the academic and the professional world. Through our training activities we aim at shortening the time of unemployment of young professionals with an educational background in social science (politics, economy, law, etc.).

We have already build a worldwide network of public and private organizations willing to provide their expertise in coaching, as well as in hosting qualified interns.   

Risks & Challenges

The main challenges will be:

  1. To reach out students and young professionals willing to participate to our training activities;
  2. Finding senior experts in their field willing to coach the younger generation;
We are planning to overcome these issues by creating strategic partnerships with universities and public and private institutions. We are already in discussion with 3 Universities, consulting companies and non-profit organizations willing to provide experts and internship opportunities. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are not in the position to contribute, help us by spreading the word around! Like our Facebook page and Twitter and share our content to create awareness!

Hello everyone,

My name is Yousef Qaraeen, and I'm a 19 year old Palestinian from East Jerusalem. I recently completed my freshman year at the Eastern Mediterranean University in Cyprus, majoring in Communications and Journalism. Thankfully, with a lot of hard work and dedication, I was able to finish with a CGPA of 3.5 and receive a high-honors award. It's important to note that this was only possible because exactly one year ago I started a fundraising campaign on this exact website that made it possible for me to pay my college fees. This is my story:

Ever since I was young, I always had a passion for reading and writing, and as I grew older I realized that I could use writing as a method to share the stories of my people, and hopefully one day make a change in my community. I began to write poetry at an early age, and in high school I won first place in two slam poetry competitions (video above). Furthermore, my love for poetry introduced me to song-writing, and ever since I was 13 I've been making music to spread the word about the oppression and struggle that my people go through. 

In addition, in 2013, I attended a summer camp in Maine, USA, known as Seeds of Peace, that revolved around ongoing conflicts in the world, specifically the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. During my time there, I learned that compromise and sacrifice are vital if we ever want to reach a mutual understanding with one another, and that sometimes it is more important to listen than it is to speak. Seeds of Peace strengthened my passion for my country, and introduced me to possibilities that I never knew existed before leaving Palestine. (Most importantly, it introduced me to incredible people that donated to my previous campaign and supported my cause with everything they had.) After my high-school graduation in 2014, I chose to attend the American University of Dubai to further continue my learning.

During my time in Dubai, I was exposed to a completely different world than the one I had seen in Palestine. I never had to fear being harassed at checkpoints, and I never had to worry about soldiers randomly stopping me to ask whether I had been incarcerated or not. Life there was simple, and I maintained high grades in all of my courses. I was an avid member of the Palestinian Culture Club, and I joined the university basketball team. Unfortunately, though, my education in Dubai was limited to one semester because the university offered no financial aid, and the money that my father had paid for me to attend my first semester left him in a great amount of debt. That is when I was faced with the greatest challenge of my life. My parents told me that there were scholarships offered for me to study in Palestine, and even abroad. These scholarships would only be given to me, though, if I changed my major to medicine or engineering. Although these two majors are very common where I come from, I find no joy or interest in doing either one. Knowing how difficult it would be for my parents, and aware of the sacrifices I had to make, I told them that I still insisted on pursuing a degree in Journalism, because that is my passion.

Instead of settling for what was offered to me, I decided to move to Cyprus and attend EMU on a 50% scholarship and major in what I love. At the time of my acceptance I knew that my parents would not be able to afford it due to the large amount of debt my father was in. That is when it occurred to me to make this page and ask for financial support. Due to the overwhelming support I received, I was able to raise enough money to pay for my first semester and begin a new chapter in my life. I finished my first year with a 3.5 CGPA, learned Turkish, helped the Palestinian basketball team win 1st place in the national competition held at EMU, and learned so many valuable life-lessons.

Unfortunately, though, today I am faced with that same obstacle I had last year. As you are aware, Palestinians have to go through numerous hurdles in order to ensure a good life and proper education for their children, due to the conflict and constant pressure from the Israeli government. My father in Palestine was recently forced to pay $6,000 to the Israeli government to keep them from demolishing our home in Jerusalem. Furthermore, he is constantly paying lawyer fees and large amounts of money to the government in order to postpone the court date in which they decide whether to demolish our house or not. He was saving that money to pay for my tuition and housing in Cyprus. In addition, I have three brothers that are currently in middle school and my parents are going through many issues to ensure that they receive the best education possible. I have tried my best to pay for my own education by getting multiple jobs in the summer. Specifically, I worked as a waiter in two hotels, I did house-keeping, tutoring, and I helped coach a basketball team. Unfortunately, though, that was barely enough for me to pay part of my tuition fees.

 In our society, it is difficult for us to put ourselves out there and to ask for help in times of distress. But if I wasn't certain that I had a purpose, and that I could make a change one day in the future, I would have taken those scholarships and studied something different. I wish that life was easy, and that I could be able to go to college without having financial worries, but I was born into a background with very limited resources. I will not let these obstacles prevent me from doing what I love and pursuing my lifelong dreams, though, and I hope that you can all see my vision. I plan to use my degree and experience in journalism to share the stories of the people who have no voice in today's world, beginning with the Palestinians living under occupation. Hopefully, my goals will bring attention to conflicts around the world and help end them.

With the 50% scholarship given to me, I have to pay approximately $2,100 a semester to attend EMU. The amount I'm attempting to raise isn't the amount needed to attend 4 years, it will only cover the next two semesters while my parents have some time to pay off the debt they're in. Any type of support is appreciated, even the smallest amount of money can make the biggest difference. Due to the current conditions, I only have two weeks to raise my funds and pay for my third semester at EMU, so please share this with anyone that you think might be able to help as soon as possible. I would like to thank those of you who are supporting my journey for the second time, it means the world to me, and nothing will go in vain I promise. If you wish to contact me regarding any questions you might have, my email is qaraeenyousef@gmail.com. Thank you for taking the time to read this, and hopefully I will be able to receive the education I dream of.

Seeds of Peace strengthened my passion for my country, and introduced me to possibilities that I never knew existed before leaving Palestine. (Most importantly, it introduced me to incredible people that donated to my previous campaign and supported my cause with everything they had.) After my high-school graduation in 2014, I chose to attend the American University of Dubai to further continue my learning.During my time in Dubai, I was exposed to a completely different world than the one I had seen in Palestine. I never had to fear being harassed at checkpoints, and I never had to worry about soldiers randomly stopping me to ask whether I had been incarcerated or not. Life there was simple, and I maintained high grades in all of my courses. I was an avid member of the Palestinian Culture Club, and I joined the university basketball team. Unfortunately, though, my education in Dubai was limited to one semester because the university offered no financial aid, and the money that my father had paid for me to attend my first semester left him in a great amount of debt. That is when I was faced with the greatest challenge of my life. My parents told me that there were scholarships offered for me to study in Palestine, and even abroad. These scholarships would only be given to me, though, if I changed my major to medicine or engineering. Although these two majors are very common where I come from, I find no joy or interest in doing either one. Knowing how difficult it would be for my parents, and aware of the sacrifices I had to make, I told them that I still insisted on pursuing a degree in Journalism, because that is my passion.Instead of settling for what was offered to me, I decided to move to Cyprus and attend EMU on a 50% scholarship and major in what I love. At the time of my acceptance I knew that my parents would not be able to afford it due to the large amount of debt my father was in. That is when it occurred to me to make this page and ask for financial support. Due to the overwhelming support I received, I was able to raise enough money to pay for my first semester and begin a new chapter in my life. I finished my first year with a 3.5 CGPA, learned Turkish, helped the Palestinian basketball team win 1st place in the national competition held at EMU, and learned so many valuable life-lessons. Unfortunately, though, today I am faced with that same obstacle I had last year. As
you are aware, Palestinians have to go through numerous hurdles in
order to ensure a good life and proper education for their children,
due to the conflict and constant pressure from the Israeli
government. My father in Palestine was recently forced to pay $6,000
to the Israeli government to keep them from demolishing our home in
Jerusalem. Furthermore, he is constantly paying lawyer fees and large
amounts of money to the government in order to postpone the court
date in which they decide whether to demolish our house or not. He was saving that money to pay for my tuition and housing in Cyprus. In addition, I have three brothers that are currently in
middle school and my parents are going through many issues to ensure
that they receive the best education possible. I have tried my best to
pay for my own education by getting multiple jobs in the summer.
Specifically, I worked as a waiter in two hotels, I did
house-keeping, tutoring, and I helped coach a basketball team.
Unfortunately, though, that was barely enough for me to pay part of my tuition fees. In our society, it is difficult for us to put ourselves out there and to ask for help in times of distress. But if I wasn't certain that I had a purpose, and that I could make a change one day in the future, I would have taken those scholarships and studied something different. I wish that life was easy, and that I could be able to go to college without having financial worries, but I was born into a background with very limited resources. I will not let these obstacles prevent me from doing what I love and pursuing my lifelong dreams, though, and I hope that you can all see my vision. I plan to use my degree and experience in journalism to share the stories of the people who have no voice in today's world, beginning with the Palestinians living under occupation. Hopefully, my goals will bring attention to conflicts around the world and help end them.With the 50% scholarship given to me, I have to pay approximately $2,100 a semester to attend EMU. The amount I'm attempting to raise isn't the amount needed to attend 4 years, it will only cover the next two semesters while my parents have some time to pay off the debt they're in. Any type of support is appreciated, even the smallest amount of money can make the biggest difference. Due to the current conditions, I only have two weeks to raise my funds and pay for my third semester at EMU, so please share this with anyone that you think might be able to help as soon as possible. I would like to thank those of you who are supporting my journey for the second time, it means the world to me, and nothing will go in vain I promise. If you wish to contact me regarding any questions you might have, my email is qaraeenyousef@gmail.com. Thank you for taking the time to read this, and hopefully I will be able to receive the education I dream of.

story:
** English Version below.


    Omdat sommigen het prefereren om Rechtstreeks te Doneren : dat wil zeggen meteen naar onze rekeningnummer zullen we per week de Tussenstanden publiceren via Facebook :

 https://www.facebook.com/groups/project.sukabumi/

rechtstreeks :  rekeningnr. NL03 INGB 0677 3701 72 t.a.v. R. de Rozario onder vermelding : Sukabumi-projects.

bankcode/swift :  INGBNL2A



                                                                                                   

                                         ONS DOEL :

Het Bewerkstelligen van een onafhankelijk LEER-CENTRUM voor minderbedeelde kinderen en Lichamelijk Gehandicapte Kinderen.

Er zijn Financiën nodig voor - het stuk grond ( 10.000m2)

                                                    - bouwmateriaal voor Een Hoofdgebouw + 6 Klaslokalen + sanitair/riolering + Medisch faciliteit + 2 guesthouses


In 4 Fases willen dit Project tot een goed einde brengen.

                                                      

         Hieronder een beknopt overzicht van onze plannen.

Fase 1 :

 € 2400 vaststellen voor de eerste aanbetaling .

                                                         Met deze aanbetaling kunnen we beginnen te werken op het land en de indeling gaan maken...een bouwschema opzetten.... Maar we mogen niet officieel gaan starten, daarvoor is een aanbetaling van 75% nodig... Deze eerste fase bewerkstelligen is heel belangrijk, omdat na een eerste aanbetaling in Indonesië veel mogelijkheden open gaan.  Gemeentelijke Instellingen, de meer bedeelde inwoners en hooggeplaatste functionarissen zijn dan meer geneigd om je Goede Doel te steunen.    Als we te kennen geven dat ons Project gesponsord wordt door Nederlanders - dan komt er nog meer Goodwill..

Foto : een gedeelte van het stuk grond waar met Jullie hulp een Leer-Centrum komt...


Fase 2: De tweede aanbetaling voldoen  ( 3600 euro ).

 

Met dit bedrag krijgen we toestemming ​​om te gaan bouwen.  Als dit bedrag via crowdfunding volbracht is dan zullen we met eigen geld + met donaties van welgestelde burgers van Sukabumi het volgende gaan bouwen :

- 6 scholen units (elk voor 2 klaslokalen)

- 6 aparte toiletten en sanitair / riolering

- Groente & fruit plantage

Inclusief betaling voor de arbeiders.


Fase 3:   De Laatste betaling voor het stuk Grond ( 2000 euro )    

de definitieve officiële papieren zal worden ondertekend.


Fase 4:   de Finale..de laatste  € 2.000.

Voor dit bedrag zullen we bouwen:

- 2 guesthouses (voor verhuur)

- 2 toiletten

- meubilair

Inclusief betaling voor de arbeiders.

- Een clubhuis / samenlevingshuis voor sport, muziek, gesprek, theater en nog veel meer ..

- Meubilair en apparatuur

- leerboeken & lesmateriaal

** Alle beginnende kosten (salaris) voor toekomstige leraren zal worden betaald uit eigen kapitaal en uit de verhuur van de 2 guesthouses en de winst van de gewassen en fruit + onze waardevolle vaste maandelijkse Nederlandse donateurs.

 ** De leerlingen produceren op de school bezems die verkocht worden.

** Privé-lessen worden gegeven aan Volwassenen en kinderen. Deze lessen zijn voor de meer welgestelde mensen uit de omgeving. Zij betalen voor deze lessen.

** We vragen ook periodieke donaties aan de meer welgestelde inwoners van de Stad .

bedankt voor de aandacht.

voor meer informatie over de reeds bestaande projecten en geschiedenis :

http://ronrozario.com/DE%20PROJECTEN/index.html

   

bedankt alvast voor de aandacht.

Ron & Karine

Voor ons is het 'makkelijk' te spiegelen met de armoede om ons heen : alhoewel we heel basic leven, voelen we ons zeer gezegend...onze eigen 3 kinderen kunnen gewoon naar school waar ze volledige daglessen krijgen met computers, goede leerkrachten en faciliteiten..schoon,veilig en kwaliteit. Om ons heen zien we andere kinderen die niet naar school gaan of alleen maar 3 uurtjes per dag basislessen krijgen van vrijwilligers of van een laag betaald leerkracht....Wij leven in een stenen huis en hoger gelegen, maar beneden de vallei wonen gezinnen in houten hutten die overstroomd worden als het flink regent....Kinderen spelen in de goot of op vuilnisplekken of op begraafplaatsen in plaats van naar school te gaan.

Gelukkig zijn er steeds meer fortuinlijke plaatselijke bewoners van bewust dat er hulp nodig is voor deze situatie. Onze Projecten krijgen stapsgewijs ook lokale aandacht. Die LEER-CENTRUM komt echt van de grond !
Maar we kunnen het niet vervolmaken naar onze ideeën zonder de hulp van onze Vrienden en kennissen.....
We gaan echt de goede kant op !

volg ons en lees de updates via :

 https://www.facebook.com/groups/project.sukabumi/






---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

                                     
                              4  PHASES  TO  ACCOMPLISH OUR GOAL :

We started early 2011 with buying schooluniforms for a few children in our neighborhood...now every year we raise funds so more children can to go to school.  Because you need a Schooluniform to be accepted to any school, even the free ones. A lot of Parents dont have money for these uniforms and for the first costs (books,school belongings)

These children from poor family can only have basic education and go to school untill 11 or 12 in the morning.  The rest of the day they wonder around or have to work .  We like to build an original centre where we can educate these children after school...with lessons in basic computer skills, English conversation, in music and Art.  We also want to create a special massage-unit where the blind children can earn a living after they get their diploma.  Please help us and the children of Java to establish these projects...

Phase 1 :

To establish 2400 euro for the first downpayment of the property.  With this downpayment we can start to work on the land and start building.  But we cannot open a school or start a bussiness .  Only with a payment of 75 % we can start properly.


Phase 2 :  To get the 75% payment.

So the next fase is to establish another 3600 euro

With this amount we are actually alowed to start building.

   With our own capital & donations from the more wealthy people of the town, we are going to build :

- 5 schoolunits ( each for 2 classrooms )

- 6 seperate toilets & plumbing

- fruit & vegetables plantation

included payment for the workers.


Phase 3 :  the last 2000 euro for final purchase of the land.

the final papers will be signed.


Phase 4 :  the Final 2000 euro.

For this amount we will build :

- 2 guesthouses ( for rental )

- 2 toilets 

- furniture

included payment for the workers.

- A Clubhouse / society house for sports , music , conversation, theater and more..

- furniture & equipments

- costs for schoolbooks & schoolmaterial

      How we are going to Pay for future expenses ?

** All the costs (salary)  for future teachers will be payed from our own capital and from the rental of the 2 guesthouses and the profits of the crops and fruit.

** We give Private lessons to Adults & children...these lessons will be payed for.

** We also ask donations from the more wealthy people of the City.

** In 2016 we will start our own Travelling Agency : the profits we will share with the Learning Centre.     We allready began with small groups.  Here is a link to this website :

http://ronrozario.com/de%20vakantie-pagina.html

Thank you for your attention.

For more information about our running projects and for more details about this crowdfunding, please go to :

http://ronrozario.com/DE%20PROJECTEN/index.html

                                       

kind regards,

 Ron & Karine

p.s. if you cannot donate by Paypall ore you want to donate instantly to a direct banknummer.   You can use this account :

NL03 INGB 0677 3701 72 

R. de Rozario / Sukabumi-projects.

bankcode/swift :  INGBNL2A

-----------------------------

story:
u·bun·tu: ˌo͝oˈbo͝on(t)o͞o/ 

noun

1. I am because we are
2. a quality that includes the essential human virtues; compassion and humanity.

My Story:

Once upon a time I found yoga.  When I found Yoga I found myself. 

 My name is Jewlz Marie. I am a professor at Santa Monica College in the Communication Studies Department and I also work as a Camp Counselor at Camp UBUNTU for the Harold Robinson Foundation.  For those of you who aren't familiar, The Harold Robinson Foundation is an amazing organization that offers enriching camp retreats to inner city schools (students/staff/parents) all year long. I dedicate the majority of my time to working with students  and  inner city youth, teaching empathy, life skills, and communication; however, I want to be able to offer these communities more.   I strongly believe that yoga can have tremendous positive impact on ones overall quality of life and wellbeing. 

This January I will be embarking on an intense month long journey to obtain my 200 hour yoga teaching certification with the International Sivananda Yoga Vedanta Centre . This campaign is important because it will allow me to obtain the certification I need to start providing inner city youth and parents with workshops that include, but are not limited to, yoga, meditation, empathy, communication, and self empowerment.  

What your contribution will help with: 

  • Tuition- $2,580
  • Textbooks- $50
  • Camping Supplies-( I'll be living in a tent for the month) Borrowing Thank you Frankey B. and Laura Wise  :  )
  • Flight- I will be using my airline miles.
  • Indiegogo fees- $210
To express gratitude and thanks for your donation I am offering several fun perks :  ) YAY!  

The Impact: 

Once I receive my teaching certification I plan to offer yoga classes and holistic workshops to individuals who might not otherwise have access to it, due to financial, social or physical constraints. My target groups will include inner city students and parents, individuals transitioning from incarceration, and domestic violence women's shelters within the Los Angeles area. These workshops will provide my students with essential tools to enhance their overall health and wellbeing. 

More about the Yoga School :

The Sivananda Ashram Yoga Retreat Bahamas follows an authentic lineage of classical yoga that was introduced to the West by Swami Vishnudevananda, a disciple of Swami Sivananda. 

Organization Mission and Vision: To spread peace, health, and joy through the practice and philosophy of yoga and Vendanta. To serve as a beacon of light in the wrold as a gathering place for learning and the exchange of ideas and experiences that impact individuals and the world in important ways.

The program requires students to study abroad so that they are fully immersed in the yogi lifestyle. The intensive daily schedule includes two meditation sessions, two yoga classes, two lectures, one hour of service to the ashram community.  One day a week is lecture-free. 

Graduates of the yoga teacher training course receive internationally recognized certification. The TTC is certified by the worldwide Yoga Alliance for the 200 hours standard for Registered Yoga Schools (RYS). 


Other Ways You Can Help

  • Please pass this along to your friends in family
  • Ubuntu:  I am because we are



                           



I spend most of my weekends working with The Harold Robinson Foundation at CAMP UBUNTU and I wouldn't have it any other way! HRF was established based on the principle that each and every child, deserves opportunities, no matter where they stand. Learn more about the amazing organization and communities I have been blessed to work with by watching the HRF2015 video.
Love and Light <3 Namaste

story:
Conferencing Places is a non profit with an attitude! Our goal is to eliminate "all" geographic & economic boundaries in Education with Video Conferencing

95% of our classrooms may not experience Video Communications in their classrooms!

There are students in our rural communities and inner city schools that have never been outside the neighborhoods or the towns they live in. They are literally living in an academic and cultural vacuum. Video Communications is absolutely the fastest way to effect change on a massive scale!

We believe that every student across America should have the same access to video based learning in the classroom. There are many obvious benefits to Video Conferencing in the classroom - here are the Top 20 uses we have identified:


click here: "Top 20" Uses for Video in the Classroom

We know this sounds like a tall order - but it can be done - so we will explain how Conferencing Places is making this happen – how you can help - and why this will work!

ConferencingPlaces.org combines three very powerful components in one highly scalable Educational Portal:

  1.  Places - find over 150,000 Schools, Libraries & Museums across America.
  2.  Faculty-Hub - Teachers find each other -share common interests.
  3. Resources-Hub - Schools can get technical help, find Tutors & Video Conferencing resources.


What we will need to grow

It’s going to cost $50,000 dollars to do this and every dollar we raise will help and will only be used to help America's classrooms.

How we plan to use your $ donations:

  1. Ongoing Web Portal development - funding for the cost of additional developers - in house or outsourced. Add more search functionality, add more content, add more Places for Educators to connect to, and add more advanced Portal features.
  2. Add Resources - fund the cost of developing Resources-Hub with Best Practice guidelines for Faculty members and create a "Painting by Numbers" approach to Video Conferencing.
  3. Promote Places, Facuty-Hub, & Resources-Hub to the Educational Community, Recruit more Tutors, Publishers, Content providers, Integrators, Technology Vendors, Consultants, and training services. Schedule Video based events and create mass adoption across all 3 components of this Portal.
  4. Add Support-Blocks so we can build and deliver Web based and live support to the Schools and classrooms that need help!
We will use any additional money that we raise to expand the services that we have built and add exciting new services. It will require significant resources to promote Conferencing Places and insure that America's teachers are getting the help they need to join this movement.


We need this money because?

We’ve built a very powerful platform to solve these glaring problems and help our classrooms connect on a massive scale! We need your support to maximize the impact this movement can have on our schools.

Conferencing Places can have an immediate impact on our schools because it will:

  • Dispel the myth surrounding Video Communications - that it's too expensive, very difficult to use with limited use. It's really is very simple, the more we can communicate to our teachers, the more they can educate with Video.
  • Reward schools that reach out and leverage the many advantages of using Video Conferencing in the classroom. We will also "expose" the schools that refuse to change because the community can help encourage and support the use of Video in the classrooms from the ground up!
  • Teach our Schools how to conduct a Video call in the classroom with or without expensive legacy Video Conferencing equipment in place. We will Help schools that do not currently have Video Conferencing use free and low cost cloud services to connect to other classrooms throughout the country.
  • Connect the dots - expand our reach by helping more faculty members find other faculty members that share common interests.
  • Provide 'best practice" so teachers can easily follow a proven format for conducting Video Conference calls with other schools and maximize their time and effort.
  • Demonstrate the many ways to use Video Conferencing and how to find and engage additional third party contributors to enhance the learning experience. Please see (below) our "Top 20" reasons to use Video Conferencing in Education.

Additional ways you can help:

Beyond just money - we ask that you help spread the word:

We would also like to ask that you share this with your friends, your local schools and any teachers that you know. You tell two people – they tell two people and on and on…………..because every child deserves the same opportunity to learn!

Ask your local school board members, Teachers & Administrators if they have Video Conferencing and if so, how often do they share their classroom learning experience with other schools.
  • Share this campaign with your network.
  • Encourage your local school Administrator to update their school's listing information and Register for ConferencingPlaces.org
  • Tell every teacher you know to create their profile on Faculty-Hub so other teachers can find them and connect their classrooms on Video.
  • Help your friends and family get involved by collectively sponsoring a local school.

Matching Donors

We are searching for matching donors to help us take Conferencing Places to the next level. There are 100,000+ schools across America and 2 1/2 million classrooms that we can all reach out to. It will require hard work and resources to reach critical mass with Video Conferencing in our schools.

Conferencing Places is a portal that addresses the "greater good" and actually extends far beyond just connecting a few classrooms. The possibilities are limitless because we are only bound by our imagination - not geography or economics.

Sum it all up

The problem:

why do so few schools use Video Conferencing and what are we doing to fix it?

There are three key reasons why America's schools have been very slow to adopt Video Conferencing in the classroom. Conferencing Places is building a platform that will solve these three most glaring obstacles to Video Communications in America’s classroom:



1) The first obstacle is cost - it is perceived to be too expensive. Schools can conduct Video Conferencing and join other classrooms for free - all they need is an internet connection and a PC!

2) The second is complexity - most schools think they need additional IT support and don't know how to connect with other schools and classrooms without IT support.

3) The third  - and the most critical component is who can you call? 
  • Who can you share your classroom with?
  • Where can you find other classrooms that share common interests?
  • How else can you leverage Video Communications to enhance the learning experience for your students? Please see out "Top 20" uses for Video Conferencing in schools below.

The solution:

ConferencingPlaces.org is a powerful Educational Portal that includes: Places, Faculty-Hub, & Resources-Hub

First - we built Places - where Educators can find over 150,000 schools, Libraries, and museums across America – all in one place. Our goal with Places is to provide a starting point that can help schools connect the dots!


Second - we built Faculty-Hub.org - this is a secure Portal for Educators where Teachers and Administrators can create their own profiles and find each other based on their common interests and specific criteria they have set!


Third - we added our Resources-Hub.org where Educators can find “all things Video”. Educators will be able to get all the help they need to connect with other classrooms across America and one day - the world!



Check out our "Top 20" uses for Video Conferencing in the classroom and support our 'Video in Every Classroom" initiative:

This is not just about reading, writing, arithmetic, or code it’s about everything and anything that can be shared in the classroom including extracurricular activities or external events! Read through the “Top 20” and imagine if this was available to your schools.

1.  Cross Pollinate your classrooms – curriculum, social/cultural & economic differences exist across our country and throughout the world – reach out and share your classroom culture with other schools. Let your students meet other classrooms around the Country – or the world!

2.  Reading – Group reading with your favorite reading platforms – visually engage with other schools on reading exercises. Invite authors to conduct a live reading of their new book or publication.

3.  Writing - live workshops – bring in writers from all over the country – or the world!

4.  Programming – Code development – collaborate and develop live with other schools - codeshare, codathon, code competitions & video based code classes with multiple schools.

5.  Live Video Conference based competitions – Spelling Bee’s, math, science, computers, architectural competitions etc….

6.  Remote student participation – Physically disabled, sick or injured children, join the classroom live!

7.  Virtual field trips – conduct virtual field trips with your classroom or multiple classrooms from anywhere in the country joining in together from multiple locations/classrooms and creating economy of scale.

8.  Special Education - including any learning disabilities - attention – retention  – all types – any subject matter – one class or multiple classrooms, leveraging economy of scale.

9.  Live Debates – between 2 schools or 100's of schools at once across the country – all on live Video! Invite celebrities etc.. to host your debates.

10.  Sports clinics – students can benefit from exposure to new technique and training regimens. Invite coaches and clinicians from around the world including professionals.

11.  Theatre – creativity sharing, live role playing, live theater – experts and celebrities can be invited.

12.  Student groups/organizations – groups, clubs - activist – bullying - anything that benefits your classroom can be connected on Video.

13.  Career days – connect with multiple classrooms from around the country and invite professional speakers. Create virtual career centers.

14.  Drug & substance abuse education – connect with a variety of public services.

15.  Safety classes – including CPR, public safety, police & fire etc…

16.  Faculty training – cross pollinate Faculty training with Video Conferencing – aggregate training resources with Video Conferencing and create economies of scale!

17.  Parent Teacher Conference – meet with parents that may not be available to attend.

18.  Animal care – teach your classroom about understanding & caring for their pets.

19.  Administrative Visual Communications – Administrators including Principals & Superintendents can conduct district wide Video Addresses’ right to the classroom or in an assembly. Administrators can meet with each other - in district or out of district without traveling.

20.  Health & human Services – conduct or join live Video Conference based Health presentations with professionals Join 1 to 1 or with multiple classrooms to aggregate multiple classrooms and create economies of scale.

We appreciate your generosity - thank you!

story:
Zoodles!

Help me combine my passion and my dream to create a place where people can use and practice their English in Trostberg, Germany!

 I’m Vickie Beck and I am an American living in beautiful Bavaria Germany. 

My passion is teaching Germans, children and adults, the English language in a creative way which I have been doing on a freelance basis for over 20 years at kindergartens, schools, businesses and even at churches around my area.

My dream, is to have a café. 

If you have ever taken a language course you know that large classrooms or an English course once a week isn’t the ideal situation for becoming more fluent in a language.

I am often asked “Vickie,where can I practice my English?”

Then the idea came to me of combining both my passion and my dream to open

I am so excited!

So much so that I spent 2 weeks in England last year working in a small café shop and visiting many others, getting lots of tips on the pro’s and con’s of the Café business.

I then proceeded to get some qualifications for opening a café in Trostberg, Germany and soon I will be taking a barista course at a local coffee roaster.

Whether you are a pupil, a student, in business, an English course attendee or a native speaker away from home, Vickie’s chat & chill is the place to go!

At Vickie’s chat & chill you can practice your English ordering an excellent cup of coffee of your choice along with something from my American and British baked goodies. Or perhaps you would like a healthy sandwich, soup or salad. Vegetarians and veganers are welcome!

After that you can enjoy an English conversation with others in the vintage styled cafe. Of course you can always chat with me!

I also see an English tea afternoon or an evening event with a musician playing softly in the background while others engage in English conversation.

People who don't speak English are more than welcome to come and maybe they will get excited about learning English and join a local English course!

As I was calculating the cost of opening a cafe I realized that I would need some financial help.

Then a friend told me about Indiegogo!

So here I am asking you to help my team and I combine my dream and my passion to open a language café and give English a home in Trostberg, Germany. I have found the perfect place.

I can't wait to start!

When you help support Vickie's chat & chill, no matter how much you give, I will frame your name in gold along with others who have helped support my project. This gold frame will then be hung in a special place for every guest to see!

I will also keep you informed via photos on progress and opening day.

How do I know this will be a success in Trostberg?

Firstly, because I have an amazing support team. 2 of my daughters who have restaurant experience, one in hotel mangement, will be assisting me in the cafe. I have a group of women who I meet with twice a month who are my " cheer leaders" reagarding this project. I also have a business coach.

Secondly,after 20 years of teaching English I have met hundreds of families and business people in this area and know that they want to use their learned English but just don’t know where.

There are 3 schools in this area totalling around 1900 pupils, 2 large companies who do international business, many English courses and tutoring institutions for pupils.

The location is within walking distance of the local schools and businesses where there are limited options for a good lunch.

Thirdly,I love to throw a party. I have had some experience in organizing events such as themed birthday parties and weddings. I am continually trying new recipes and my hobbies are decorating, sewing and remodelling old furniture.

Fourthly, our German foster children loved the healthy American food that was served  in our home and when they come to visit they often ask for one of their favorites.

And finally, after making this project known to people, I haven't had one negative response. People have started asking when opening day is.


What I need?

A commercial red espresso coffee machine along with a coffee bean grinder and milk pot etc... This will be the largest cost at around 11,000 Euros.

Kitchen equipment such as fridge, stove, oven, commercial dishwasher, countertops and cupboards etc...6,000 Euros

Renovation of the rooms into a vintage Café including new flooring: 3,000 Euros

Interior for the Café such as the counter,  table and chairs, lighting and some costs of reupholstering:3,000-5,000 Euros

Dishware, pots and pans:500 Euros

Advertising and logo and the first round of “ to go” cups and lunch bags:2,000 Euros

Cashier program and equipment as well as phone system. 500 Euros

The first stock of merchandise. 500-1,000 Euros

The front entrance and sign: 500 Euros

Then there are also costs for the legal side of opening a café and the security deposit for renting the venue.3,000 Euros

Thanks so much for sharing my project with your friends and family via your social networks!

story:
What Kind of School is Aristoi?

Aristoi Classical Academy is a tuition-free charter school in Katy, Texas offering a classical education to over 530 students in grades K-9. Since 2012, enrollment has grown by more than 200 students because Aristoi is providing an excellent educational option for our community.

Classical education is usually offered in expensive private schools . Aristoi is a public school providing a private-school-quality education to children from all socioeconomic backgrounds.

What's So Different About Classical Education?

The twin and indivisible aims of classical education are knowledge and virtue.  Aristoi Classical Academy is a part of a growing nationwide movement to reclaim America’s educational heritage by restoring a concept of education that is first and foremost in service of the student as a human being.  We believe that such an education is also the best way to prepare students to be responsible and virtuous Americans.  

Parents are rightly concerned that many schools are focused on standardized testing and job-skills training rather than developing the character and intellect of American students. Aristoi seeks to help reform public education by getting back to what matters-pursuing excellence in its students as individuals and as citizens.

Here are a few classical elements that make Aristoi different from other public schools:

  • Study of classic literature at all grade levels
  • Use of Socratic dialogue school-wide to promote critical thinking and logical argument
  • Study of Latin
  • In-depth study of American and world history beginning in kindergarten
  • Emphasis on the development of character and virtue

Find out more about Classical Education at Aristoi here: What is Classical Education?

Why Aristoi Needs a New Campus

This year, Aristoi's enrollment is just over 530 students in grades K-9. Our current campus holds only 440 students in grades K-5, so the school has leased additional classroom space off campus to house the junior high and high school students.  While the school raises funds to build a new school, it will continue to lease space to accommodate the junior high and high school students.

In the fall of 2015, Aristoi will add 10th grade.  In the fall of 2016, Aristoi will add 11th grade. The following year, Aristoi will welcome its first graduating class--the class of 2018! 

When the school's projected growth is complete, enrollment will total approximately 900 students.

A new campus is not a desire--it's an urgent need!

Plans to Develop the New Campus in Stages

The new campus will be developed in stages, as funding permits.  If we raise enough funds, the school can work on multiple stages simultaneously. Here's the most likely development scenario:

  • Stage 1 -  Purchase of property.
  • Stage 2 - Construct a building for upper school students, plus a gymnasium.
  • Stage 3 - Construct a building for the elementary school.
  • Items that can be constructed during any stage, depending on funding - library, auditorium/performing arts center, sports fields.
Right now, grades K-5 have the classroom space they need on the school's main campus; however, the classrooms are small and there is not enough room for a library. 

State Funding is Not Enough

Charter schools receive less funding per student than traditional public school districts and they receive no tax dollars to purchase or maintain facilities. The traditional public schools raise taxes when they need a new school but, as a charter, Aristoi isn't allowed to do the same.  That's why it's necessary for Aristoi to ask for help to raise outside funds.

Why Such a Large Goal?

Land in Katy, Texas is expensive.  To purchase land and develop a campus, it will cost millions of dollars.

We set our Indiegogo goal at $1,100,000 because that's the price of the land we're planning to purchase and develop for the new K-12 campus.  If we raise more than our goal here, that will put Aristoi in a much better position to get timely financing to build buildings. It's important to pay as much as we can up front in order to take on the minimum debt burden possible.

The Challenges Ahead

Most Aristoi families come from modest means and are unable to give large contributions.  But everyone can ask for help from friends, family members and businesses.  Every dollar helps!

Whatever Aristoi raises here will be used to move toward development of a new campus.  Even if we don't reach the goal on this campaign, the money you give will be applied toward Aristoi's expansion project.  The school will seek financing to cover what we don't raise.

There will be many steps to take in building a new campus and each will be costly. Here are a few of the initial costs we expect:

  • Purchase land
  • Hire an architect to design the campus and buildings
  • Put in water, sewer and electric systems
  • Prepare the grounds for building
  • Break ground and begin construction

How You Can Help

Share this campaign with friends, family, charitable organizations known to support education, and anyone else who might be willing to help.  Donations can be as small as $1!  Donors can give from all over the world.

Aristoi is a nonprofit corporation, so all contributions are tax deductible!
story_txt:
What Kind of School is Aristoi?Aristoi Classical Academy is a tuition-free charter school in Katy, Texas offering a classical education to over 530 students in grades K-9. Since 2012, enrollment has grown by more than 200 students 
because Aristoi is providing an excellent educational option for 
our community.Classical education is usually offered in expensive private schools . Aristoi is a public school providing a private-school-quality education to children from all socioeconomic backgrounds.What's So Different About Classical Education?The twin and indivisible aims of classical education are knowledge and
virtue.  Aristoi
Classical Academy is a part of a growing nationwide movement to reclaim
America’s educational heritage by restoring a concept of
education that is first and foremost in service of the student as a human being.  We
believe that such an education is also the best way to prepare students to be responsible and virtuous Americans.  Parents are rightly concerned that many schools are focused on standardized testing and job-skills training rather than developing the character and intellect of American students. Aristoi seeks to help reform public education by getting back to what matters-pursuing excellence in its students as individuals and as citizens. Here are a few classical elements that make Aristoi different from other public schools:
Study of classic literature at all grade levels 

Use of Socratic dialogue school-wide to promote critical thinking and logical argument
Study of Latin 

In-depth study of American and world history beginning in kindergarten
Emphasis on the development of character and virtue

Find out more about Classical Education at Aristoi here: What is Classical Education?
Why Aristoi Needs a New Campus This year, Aristoi's enrollment is just over 530 students in grades K-9. Our current campus holds only 440 students in grades K-5, so the school has leased additional classroom space off campus to house the junior high and high school students.  While the school raises funds to build a new school, it will continue to lease space to accommodate the junior high and high school students.In the fall of 2015, Aristoi will add 10th grade.  In the fall of 2016, Aristoi will add 11th grade. The following year, Aristoi will welcome its first graduating class--the class of 2018!  When the school's projected growth is complete, enrollment will total approximately 900 students.A new campus is not a desire--it's an urgent need!Plans to Develop the New Campus in StagesThe new campus will be developed in stages, as funding permits.  If we raise enough funds, the school can work on multiple stages simultaneously. Here's the most likely development scenario:
Stage 1 -  Purchase of property.
Stage 2 - Construct a building for upper school students, plus a gymnasium.
Stage 3 - Construct a building for the elementary school.
Items that can be constructed during any stage, depending on funding - library, auditorium/performing arts center, sports fields.
Right now, grades K-5 have the classroom space they need on the school's main campus; however, the classrooms are small and there is not enough room for a library.  State Funding is Not EnoughCharter schools receive less funding per student than traditional public school districts and they receive no tax dollars to purchase or maintain facilities. The traditional public schools raise taxes when they need a new school but, as a charter, Aristoi isn't allowed to do the same.  That's why it's necessary for Aristoi to ask for help to raise outside funds.Why Such a Large Goal?Land in Katy, Texas is expensive.  To purchase land and develop a campus, it will cost millions of dollars. We set our Indiegogo goal at $1,100,000 because that's the price of the land we're planning to purchase and develop for the new K-12 campus.  If we 
raise more than our goal here, that will put Aristoi in a much better 
position to get timely financing to build buildings. It's important to pay as much as we can up front in order to take on the minimum debt burden possible.The Challenges AheadMost Aristoi families come from modest means and are unable to give large contributions.  But everyone can ask for help from friends, family members and businesses.  Every dollar helps!Whatever Aristoi raises here will be used to move toward development of a new campus.  Even if we don't reach the goal on this campaign, the money you give will be applied toward Aristoi's expansion project.  The school will seek financing to cover what we don't raise. There will be many steps to take in building a new campus and each will be costly. Here are a few of the initial costs we expect:
Purchase land
Hire an architect to design the campus and buildings

Put in water, sewer and electric systems
Prepare the grounds for building
Break ground and begin construction

How You Can Help Share this campaign with friends, family, charitable organizations known to support education, and anyone else who might be willing to help.  Donations can be as small as $1!  Donors can give from all over the world.Aristoi is a nonprofit corporation, so all contributions are tax deductible!

story:
Help an Older Brother Publish a Departed Younger Brother's Legacy

Help me finish my brother's dream of publishing a children's book, written for the children of Northern New Mexico's Native American Indian reservations.

My Story

A lifetime ago, my brother's wanted to be a doctor. A quick student, he finished medical school a full year ahead of schedule. Unfortunately, he couldn't practice medicine without that 4th year! Determined, Dr. Carl took a chance and traveled to Northern New Mexico.

While working on the Indian reservations, Dr. Carl grew to care for the families and became a trusted friend. Inspired, he wrote a children's book: Pinto, the Magic Horse. He wanted to publish the book for the children of the 32 reservations in the Northern New Mexico area.

The Impact

40 years later, I want to finish what he started. My goal is to finish the illustrations and publish copies for every 1st grade child of the 32 reservations my brother loved. To do this, I need your help!

What I Need & What You Get

Back then, my brother asked me for $100 to finish his book. Today, I am asking for your help to complete his legacy. By donating, you are giving them a frame of their heritage that is not about conflict, but hope!

Other Ways To Help

tell your friends about my campaign. Thank you in advance! If you can't donate at this time, please share my story via social media, email and word of mouth to
