story:
Short Summary

Children's Paradise is a unique school in Pokhara, Nepal, supporting both mainstream children and those with learning disabilities; autism, ADHD etc.
There is very little support and education for children with these conditions in Nepal. Often the children are not accepted in school or society and are left all day, sometimes in a locked room, with no interaction with other children or adults.
I've worked with people with learning disabilities, in England, for the last 10 years and want to share my skills with the teachers and families here in Nepal, giving them hope for the future of their children.
At present, the school supports the children with learning disabilities alongside the typical pre-school children, great whilst the child is still young, but not an ideal situation as they get older (8-9 year old children alongside 2-3year olds). I want to support the principal in developing the school by creating a 'day care' provision for the older children with learning disabilities and teaching them life skills to enable them to hopefully become independent in the future.

What We Need

On a temporary basis, we will start daycare from the principal's own home (a rented building). To resource this, I've estimated we need £1,500. This will enable us to purchase the following:
  • Arts and craft materials; paper, pens, scissors, paint etc
  • Individual personal hygiene products (to teach children independent self care)
  • Sensory items, bubbles, balloons, musical items
  • Toys and games, puzzles, balls hula hoops etc
  • Gardening items (to learn farming skills)
  • Ride on trike, see-saw.

The Impact

In Nepal, people with disabilities struggle to be accepted in society and this results in their families being marginalised too. Firstly, there is little education about their child's needs but also they are often blamed for the child being the way they are; they are accused of having 'a bad spirit'.
Unlike western countries, there is no financial support/aid. Often children miss out on vital doctor's appointments, because the families can't afford the expense or indeed understand the importance of them.
My hope is to show these families and wider society that these children can achieve and contribute to society; that they have value.
Alongside the daycare, I hope to provide monthly parent support sessions. The purpose of these sessions would be two fold. To help break down the isolation parents feel, letting them know they are not alone, but also to act as teaching sessions, helping them understand more about their child's condition and providing emotional support in the challenging task of parenting a child that's not valued in their society.
Please visit www.childrenpokhara.com to find out more about what the school is already doing.
This is a small project, but for the children and families involved it will make an amazing difference to their lives and their enjoyment of life. It gives them a clear message that they matter, they have value, that they are worth caring about.
Those of you who know me are aware that I have grown up as part of a fostering family for 28 years, so have lived with children who've experienced labelling, rejection and loss. For 10 of those years, I've also worked with people with learning disabilities and my heart is to bring warmth, acceptance and love to those who are often overlooked or rejected by society. I've seen first hand how consistent care and encouragement can help someone move from a position of loneliness and despair to starting to believe in themselves, accepting that they too have the right to dreams and striving to reach them.      
That's what I long to bring to these children and their families - that belief that life really can be different and worth living.

Risks & Challenges

As with all crowd funding sites, you have to trust that the money you give will be used in the way described, but as so many of you already know me from work, church, social activities etc, I hope you have the confidence that I will ensure the money is used with integrity and wisdom. 
At present, the school has few resources and the day care will be starting from scratch, so it will be slow progress for a while, but follow the blog on the Children's Paradise webpage you can see where your money is being spent and also follow the individual stories of the children.
We'll certainly face some challenges in establishing this project - not least from the families themselves, who may be understandably fearful of the emotional cost of bringing their children out in public and taking them to the school. Then there's the people who'll think that because I'm a white tourist that I'll have lots of money to spend and who'll hope to fleece me when I buy items for the children. 
I'm on a learning curve too, being a young woman in a different culture working with the bare minimum of Nepali language skills and still learning what's acceptable here and what will alienate people. However, I'm also sensible enough not to try and do this on my own, so I'll take advice from people here and abroad that I know and trust, people with a good understanding of Nepal, its society, disability, social justice and implementing new start social care projects. I'll take time to reflect on what I see and hear and share it with those people and seek advice before makiing decisions.
Knwoing you're entrusting me with your money is an awesome responsibility and I want to make it work well in this situation, so I'll treat it with care and respect, recognising what it has cost you to earn it and understanding that you want to see it used effectively. I'll keep simple, but transparent accounts and ensure you receive quarterly reports of how it's been spent and the difference it's made.        

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can donate, even just a small amount, that would be fantastic but I understand that for some this is not possible. However, you can still help this project, please share this page, talk about it with friends, get the word out there.
Do you want to see the work in action? Well, Children's Paradise welcomes volunteers, so check out the website for information on volunteering in the school or daycare. I look forward to meeting you! :-)
Folks, whatever you can give willl make a difference and I send you a huge thank you from the bottom of my heart
X x

I'll keep simple, but transparent accounts and ensure you receive quarterly reports of how it's been spent and the difference it's made.           Other Ways You Can Help

story:
"The real purpose of running isn’t to win a race, it’s to test the limits of the human heart." 

- Bill Bowerman, Co-Founder of Nike

The Story

Thank you for visiting my Indie Go Go page!  My name is Melissa Neubart, and I am running my first-ever half-marathon for After-School All-Stars. 

My story starts one day last November when I was running along the Hudson River in Jersey City, New Jersey. I was two months into my new position with After-School All-Stars Newark and New York, and, as with any job, I had a lot on my plate: a fresh environment, new colleagues, and learning the ropes of a new organization. I was extremely excited for this new opportunity given to me, but I knew I was beginning a journey that was going to push my limits. On this particular fall day, I’d gotten home, put my running shoes on and hit the pavement. Within moments, my mind was clear, and the stressors that once seemed vast and overwhelming, seemed miniscule as I looked across the river to the NYC skyline… what was I stressed out about again?

During that run along the river in November, I decided that I was going to run a half-marathon. Wait—I thought—what am I thinking—how am I going to run a half-marathon? It sounded good, but the longest distance I had ever run was 4 miles. I knew that if I really was going to stick with this ambitious goal for myself, I was going to do it for After-School All-Stars (ASAS). What better way to motivate myself than to support the amazing organization I work for? 

After-School All-Stars

Many, if not all of you, know of our founder, Arnold Schwarzenegger. He founded ASAS over 20 years ago as Inner City Games Foundation, bringing sports to youth nationwide to build self-confidence and self-reliance. Inner City Games changed its name to reflect its development into a school-based, comprehensive national organization. Today, ASAS serves over 85,000 youth nationally every single day providing free, engaging, after-school programming around academics, health and fitness, and enrichment. We work in inner-city schools for amazing kids that need it most.

Without ASAS, students may not have a safe environment to go to once class ends or a parent waiting at home for them once they leave the school building. ASAS provides a fun, creative, engaging atmosphere that attributes to their success as a student and lifelong learner. In addition, every student gets one hour of physical activity a day.

What We Need & What You Get

Because of our amazing supporters, each one of our students get to attend our programs at NO cost. My goal is to raise $30,000 by April 26, 2015, the date of my half-marathon.  100% of the funding will go DIRECTLY to support the 800 kids receiving life-changing programs in Newark and New York City.  

I am on a mission and a timeline to reach my goal! 

We have fun and exciting perks to thank you! Firstly, every donor will receive a hand-written thank you letter from an All-Star! We hope that in addition to our cause, our perks will get you excited to contribute! 

We have teamed up with sponsors to offer prizes, including a year long workout plan from Cody: By donating at any level, you will be entered into a raffle to be chosen as 1 of the 5 winners to win the workout plan. 

               

The Impact

If you are looking to make an impact today, invest in After-School All-Stars.  Each and every All-Star staff member I have met throughout the 15 chapters is truly invested in seeing the success of the students we serve. The Program Leaders are "kid-magnets" and they are the magic folks that keep the All-Stars engaged and attending our programs! ASAS creates opportunities for students to become successful both personally and professionally. 

Independent evaluations have shown that ASAS participants exhibit significant improvements across the board—from higher attendance to increased motivation to graduate high school. Reading and math achievement gains equivalent to one month of additional schooling, 14% better school attendance, 17% reduction in suspensions and a 33% decrease in discipline referrals.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute monetarily, there are other ways to support us! 

  • Get the word out and make some noise about the campaign! Send an email to your family and friends about the campaign, and share on social media. 
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools for the easiest way to spread the word!

You can follow my half-marathon journey through my Muscle & Fitness Hers Blog - http://www.muscleandfitnesshers.com/blogs/athlete/melissa-neubart

Photography by http://rb3photography.com 

Thank you Generation Iron for producing the video! www.generationiron.com

story:
FORUNDIO  FESTIVAL  (teatro, musica, arte varia e natura)

30-31 luglio 1-2-agosto 2015

Buongiorno a tutti siamo Bianca e Cesare della 'Compagnia Teatro Scalzo' di Genova.

 Il nostro progetto è quello di rendere il festival un appuntamento fisso, sede di eventi culturali e artistici, fruibile e aperto a chiunque possa "ritrovarsi" in una località decisamente poco turistica ma strettamente legata alla natura.


Chiunque volesse partecipare al nostro progetto e aiutarci in qualsiasi modo, sarebbe di grande aiuto. Il progetto è molto vasto e richiede per ogni edizione un grande sforzo fisico, organizativo ed economico, per questo c'è bisogno di condivisione, sostegno morale, nuove relazioni umane.

Il primo passo verso la realizzazione di questo progetto è stato organizzare nel 2007 la prima edizione del festival

Ad oggi abbiamo realizzato 8 edizioni e stiamo preparando la nona.

Finora non siamo riusciti ad avere finanziamenti,  ma siamo fiduciosi nelle nostre risorse, nell'aiuto di altri colleghi, nell'arrivo di turisti/spettatori o sponsor. Crediamo che con la buona volontà si possa riuscire ad ottenere qualcosa, anche se fossero solo valide relazioni umane: solo il piacere di realizzare qualcosa di bello ci spinge ogni anno a continuare a farlo.



Faggio Rotondo si trova nell'entroterra ligure (Genova), immerso nella natura, con la vista del mare all'orrizzonte.


E' necessario percorrere un tratto pedonale (20 minuti circa a seconda di dove si parcheggia), ma per anziani, donne incinte o con bambini molto piccoli o portatori di handikap, siamo disponibili ad accompagnarvi alla meta con un nostro mezzo.

GIORNATA TIPO:

ore 8 escursione (mattinata)

ore 9/10 laboratorio yoga

ore 10/12 laboratorio di teatro

 ore 10/12 laboratorio di danze popolari

 ore 13 pranzo

ore 16/17 laboratorio di circo

ore 17/18 laboratorio costruzione muro a secco

ore 18/19 spettacolo teatrale per bambini

 ore 20.30 cena

ore 21,30 spettacolo teatrale / concerto

ore 23 cinema

COSTI


Il Festival è completamente gratuito, ad eccezione dei pasti (la cucina è vegetariana (e su richiesta anche vegana) comunque a prezzi contenuti


OBIETTIVI

Ci siamo posti un traguardo, cioè di raggiungere la cifra di 7500 euro.

questo è quello che servirebbe per:

a livello logistico: miglioramento zona campeggio, potenziamento punti acqua e relative cisterne, segnalazione percorsi, illuminazione, panche e tavole zona pasti, miglioramento impianto elettrico, miglioramento raccolta differenziata (acquisto contenitori), potenziamento cucina (acquisto frigo), rifacimento palco con tettoia, rifacimento zona bar, miglioramento strada, pannelli solari per acqua calda, pulizia dei sentieri di accesso, segnaletica per raggiungere il festival, ...

a livello artistico: budget per i vari gruppi musicali, teatrali, circensi, performer vari, pubblicità, potenziamento service audio luci, acquisto luci led a basso consumo.

Al di là di come andrà questa raccolta fondi, sappiamo che in ogni caso il "9° Forundio Festival" ci sarà come ogni anno.

 con il vostro aiuto speriamo di poter fare tutti quei miglioramenti che altrimenti sarebbero impensabili!!!

oltre all'aspetto economico( ognuno può donare quello che ritiene giusto), ci farebbe piacere sentire di non essere soli in questa avventura. ogni anno il festival è stato fatto grazie all'energia di un gruppo di amici, che si sono operati i giorni del festival e quelli prima destinati alla preparazione, con la unica meta di arrivare a realizzare questo evento. non c'è per nessuno un ritorno economico e crediamo che sia un valore fondamentale.

in ogni caso oltre alle vostre donazioni, potete aiutarci anche solo condividendo il progetto sui vari social network e soprattutto partecipando al festival!

grazie

a tutti

il Team del Forundio Festival

Bianca, Cesare, Corrado, Cristina, Giulia, Lino, Rosanna, Enzo, Damiano, Cinzia, Mabel, Mauizio, Federico, Silvana

 -----------------------

Per qualsiasi informazione scriveteci a info@teatroscalzo.it oppure telefonate o messaggio a:

Bianca 347.4038237

Cesare 349.8229621

grazie!
story_txt:
FORUNDIO  FESTIVAL 
(teatro, musica, arte varia e natura)30-31 luglio 1-2-agosto 2015
Buongiorno a tutti siamo Bianca e Cesare
della 'Compagnia Teatro Scalzo' di Genova.
 Il nostro progetto è quello di rendere il festival un appuntamento fisso, sede di eventi culturali e artistici, fruibile e
aperto a chiunque possa "ritrovarsi" in una località decisamente poco
turistica ma strettamente legata alla natura.

Chiunque volesse partecipare al nostro
progetto e aiutarci in qualsiasi modo, sarebbe di grande aiuto. Il progetto è
molto vasto e richiede per ogni edizione un grande sforzo fisico, organizativo ed economico, per questo c'è bisogno di condivisione, sostegno morale, nuove relazioni umane.
Il primo passo verso la realizzazione di
questo progetto è stato organizzare nel 2007 la prima edizione del festival 
Ad oggi abbiamo realizzato 8 edizioni e
stiamo preparando la nona.
Finora non siamo riusciti ad avere
finanziamenti,  ma siamo fiduciosi
nelle nostre risorse, nell'aiuto di altri colleghi, nell'arrivo di
turisti/spettatori o sponsor. Crediamo che con la buona volontà si possa
riuscire ad ottenere qualcosa, anche se fossero solo valide relazioni umane: solo il piacere di realizzare qualcosa di bello ci spinge ogni anno a continuare a farlo.
Faggio Rotondo si trova nell'entroterra
ligure (Genova), immerso nella natura, con la vista del mare all'orrizzonte.
E' necessario percorrere un tratto
pedonale (20 minuti circa a seconda di dove si parcheggia), ma per anziani,
donne incinte o con bambini molto piccoli o portatori di handikap, siamo
disponibili ad accompagnarvi alla meta con un nostro mezzo.
GIORNATA TIPO:
ore 8 escursione (mattinata)ore 9/10 laboratorio yoga

ore 10/12 laboratorio di teatro
 ore
10/12 laboratorio di danze popolari
 ore
13 pranzo
ore 16/17 laboratorio di circo
ore 17/18 laboratorio costruzione muro a secco
ore 18/19 spettacolo teatrale per bambini
 ore
20.30 cena
ore 21,30 spettacolo teatrale / concertoore 23 cinema
COSTI
Il Festival è completamente gratuito, ad
eccezione dei pasti (la cucina è vegetariana (e su richiesta anche vegana) comunque a prezzi

story:
My name is Gabriel Carrazana, I am fifteen years old and live in Charlottesville, Virginia.  I am going to Guanaja on a missions trip with my church this July.  We will be there for 10 days, during which we will fix houses, do odd jobs, and many other things. Although these are all important we will focus on the children. Their children are their future, and we want their future to be good, so we will spend much of our time teaching and spending time with the kids.  We will also be creating a friendly environment, a family environment where the children will be safe and feel loved. 

My church is a very small church, about a hundred people.  This is the first international missions team our church has sent in decades.  As of now we are short on funding, please consider making donation no matter how small!

story:
Short Summary

Founded in 2010, iCENTER Community Foundation is a Florida nonprofit 501(c) (3) community based multi-service youth and family development agency. Our mission is to assist at-risk youth and young adults, this includes youths developmental delays and those preparing and/or transitioning out of foster care and to independent living.

While many children have no academic issues with learning to do math, read and write while sitting at an assigned desk and completing worksheets; many others aren’t so lucky. They have trouble sitting at their desks for extended periods of time; they need to move around and touch things to learn most effectively.

Such is the case with Kinesthetic learners, who learn best by moving their bodies, activating their large or small muscles as they learn. These are the "hands-on learners" or the "doers" who actually concentrate better and learn more easily when movement is involved. The following characteristics are often associated with kinesthetic learners.

1. Kinesthetic learners often wiggle, tap their feet, or move their legs when they sit.

2. Kinesthetic learners were often labeled "hyperactive" as children.

3. Because they learn through movement, kinesthetic learners often do well as performers: athletes, actors, or dancers.

4. Kinesthetic learners work well with their hands. They may be good at repairing work, sculpting, art, or working with various tools.

5. Kinesthetic learners are often well coordinated and have a strong sense of timing and body movement.

What We Need & What You Get

Funding will be used to develop a state of the art facility that will include fitness kiosks that are attached to monitors. Monitors will be uploaded with academic material and drills to allow youth to study and improve physical fitness simultaneously. This is a practice known as Action Based Learning. Our ultimate goal is to utilize physical fitness programing to ensure that students’ attention to detail, visual discrimination, comprehension and executive thinking becomes as natural as breathing.

The Impact

Our program is based on research by Dr. John J. Ratey, a professor at the Harvard Medical School. He has demonstrated the scientific connection between exercise and brain performance.

Physical fitness is associated with academic performance in young people, according to a report presented at the American Heart Association's 2010 Conference on Nutrition, Physical Activity and Metabolism. 
Furthermore, researchers have found that students who had the highest average scores in standardized reading, math, science and social studies tests were those students who were fit at the start and end of the study. Participants will be able to improve their academic performance in the classroom. Thereby increasing their likelihood of succeeding beyond the classroom while increase their physical fitness in a society that has been identified as unhealthy physically and mentally.

Implementation of this program will:

INCREASE ATTENTION

INCREASE COMPREHENSION

INCREASE RETENTION

INCREASE TEST SCORES

Risks & Challenges

Among the 43 states that in 1998 were gathering information on their students’ performance on the National Assessment of Educational Progress (NAEP), Florida had the fifth-lowest 4th-grade reading scores.

The following evidence (Chomitz et al, 2009) highlights the relationship of physical activity to cognitive development. Physical activity and physical fitness have been shown to have positive effects on cognition and concentration.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand some people cannot  contribute, we thank you for your consideration and ask that you help us get the word out and make some noise about our campaign. Additionally, we are enthusiast about volunteers and organizational sponsors varies programs and projects.

Please use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

story:
The Idea

  • In an effort to expand students' horizons, we have decided to begin holding after-school ukulele classes for our students. Other than a few hand drums, there are no musical instruments available at the school for our students to play, which means that our music program is very limited. By creating this program (which we have named the Ukuleleague) and instructing both students and teachers, we hope to begin a legacy of musical instruction that will extend for years to come.
  • Our ukulele instructor will be Mr. Drew Kimzey, a Peace Corps volunteer from the United States. He has been a musician for twenty years.
  • By donating to this program, you will enable  students now and in the future to gain an understanding and appreciation of music in a way that would not have been possible before. You will be opening doors for students who might someday become lifelong musicians.

What We Need & What You Get

  • Our goal is to purchase ten Kala Makala MK-S Soprano Ukuleles, priced at $70 each (including shipping from the United States.)
  • Each person or organization who gives a donation will receive a video from a student at Grand Roy Government School, thanking you for your support and playing you a short piece of music on the ukulele that you helped us purchase.
  • If we do not reach our funding goal, we will use the money to buy as many ukuleles as we can, and save the remaining sum to purchase the remainder in the future.

Why Musical Education is Important

  • Students learn to improve their work: Learning music promotes craftsmanship, and students learn to want to create good work instead of mediocre work. This desire can be applied to all subjects of study.
  • Musical training helps develop language and reasoning: Students who have early musical training will develop the areas of the brain related to language and reasoning. The left side of the brain is better developed with music, and songs can help imprint information on young minds.
  • Students learn pattern recognition: Children can develop their math and pattern-recognition skills with the help of musical education. Playing music offers repetition in a fun format.
  • Better self-confidence: With encouragement from teachers and parents, students playing a musical instrument can build pride and confidence. Musical education is also likely to develop better communication for students.
  • Music builds imagination and intellectual curiosity: Introducing music in the early childhood years can help foster a positive attitude toward learning and curiosity. Artistic education develops the whole brain and develops a child’s imagination.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • If you know anyone else who you think would like to support musical education for underprivileged children, please spread the word about the Grand Roy UkuleLeague. We want to make a lasting impact on this school and community, and we cannot do it without your support.

story:
Jhulley! (Greetings in Ladakhi) 

I am a designer and educator dedicated to child-friendly learning.  My work is primarily inspired by the sublime values of limitless compassion, mindfulness and human connection. 



THE STORY

I happened to visit Ladakh for the first time in the Autumn of 2005 and it created a lasting impression. Ladakh, the high mountain plateau surrounding the upper Indus valley, stands at a geographical and cultural crossroads between Tibet, Central Asia, Persia and India. Long closed off due to its disputed borders with China and Pakistan, the region has become a popular tourist destination, and is rapidly becoming more integrated with the rest of India. 

After initial visits to the region, I realised that beyond this breathtaking mountainous terrain that holds great appeal for tourists, there was another world where the children were very eager to learn and support was required to hone their talents. 

My skills lie in designing educational modules that evoke imagination, enhance creativity and set young learners out on the path of inquiry-based learning. In 2011,  I stayed for 3 months, and taught at two monastery schools and visited remote schools where children facing adversity were provided some means to education. Having previously taught and trained with primary school children, I recognised the deficiencies quickly. In their cherubic smiles and sharp minds, I saw ample potential. And that is when Avalokitesvara Trust was born... 

                  

One of the keys projects currently run under the umbrella of the Avalokiteśvara Trust is FOUNTAIN OF LEARNING. Fountain of Learning a.k.a FOL, is an initiative to nurture and educate children in isolated villages of Ladakh. In the last 4 years, FOL has created reading rooms and libraries in Ladakh, a remote ice desert region of the western Himalaya.

PROJECTS AND ACHIEVEMENTS SO FAR..

FoL began with engagement in one or two local monastery schools, with the intention to create tools and skills to make learning and compassion thrive in the classroom. FoL joined hands with other isolated and neglected schools across Ladakh, towards both the Indo-China and Indo-Pakistan borders.

In the expanded project area, we have accomplished the following:

  • Sourcing and collection of children's books and setting up reading rooms The books are carefully selected by the team according to suitability for Ladakhi children. These include 3 levels of reading based on age-group and ability. So far from our base in Leh, we have set up 40 reading rooms and book corners in schools and learning centres, stocking them with a range of materials, mostly childrens' books, in all the languages taught here - Hindi, Urdu, English and Ladakhi/Tibetan. Some books are also bilingual (English-Hindi). The reading rooms are set up in existing schools, repainted and refurbished with furniture designed by us in traditional style primarily reading desks and shelves.
  • Implementing health and hygiene modules Children here are prone to respiratory, skin and bone problems due to the dry cold climate in Ladakh. There is a lack of hygiene awareness and facilities. We conduct fun and friendly modules for children which educate them in basic hygiene and its importance. 
  • Pedagogical material, educational games and sports equipmentThese include mathematical kits for pre-primary and primary schools that introduce number operations and logical abilities to the students, flash cards and language aids to assist effective learning in our reading programmes. Our volunteers have conducted football, yoga and physical awareness modules and also distributed equipment for sports and outdoor games.
  • Empowering Ladakhi teachers with educational resources, teaching aids and training programs One of our long term goals is to introduce and empower local teachers with ideas, methods and resources to encourage creative and experience-based learning, expanding the focus beyond curricular rote-learning. This is done through both organised workshops and the gradual building of a personal network of trained volunteers and interested teachers.
  • Translating and publishing childrens' books We are interested in publishing translations of select childrens’ books in local languages. Our first is a Ladakhi translation of ‘Chuskit goes to School’, in collaboration with Pratham Books. 

  • Volunteer Programme We orient and train volunteers with a structured pedagogy. They are appointed to teach children and train teachers at schools with these approaches to learning in the area of language, arts and maths. You can read the experiences shared by the volunteers here



                                


                      


FoL is a slow labour of dedication and love that has brought me deeper insights into their lives and while ‘educating,’ I have learnt and unlearnt a lot from them. Filling a classroom with love and connection, safety and trust, enthusiasm and the joy for learning encourages children to tap into their true creative potential. If we are to ignite young minds and a play a role in moulding them into self-confident, mindful and sensitive beings, let us do this gradually, with gentle encouragement and with the freedom to enjoy their childhoods. Each and every child, irrespective of his or her family or financial background, deserves a chance to go to school, to read and write, to explore, to discover and to learn, play and grow; while truly enjoying the process of learning! And it is said that where compassion thrives, so does learning!

-Abhigya Shukla Akester 

Founder & Director, Avalokitesvara Trust   



THE IMPACT AND IT'S IMPORTANCE

Children in remote areas of Ladakh are not receiving adequate support towards an enriching learning experience. Many schools do not have proper facilities, let alone a library. These children miss out on learning opportunities that can open them up to the world outside the mountainous terrain they live in. This project aims to offer an opportunity to these children who otherwise have been neglected.

The project supports existing private, government, monastic schools and learning centres by developing better facilities and supplies imperative for the efficient running of these schools. These facilities include creating reading rooms, volunteer programmes, conducting periodic educational and teacher training workshops. We further seek to support these needy schools with necessary educational, recreational, medical, sports and other relevant support.

Since its inception in 2011, the project has expanded swiftly and naturally, in response to the widespread need, and positive reception of our earlier work. From beginnings in one or two monastery schools, with the aim of enhancing educational resources and experiences for the children of Ladakh, the project has reached out to a much larger number of schools of all kinds across the region, and begun to contemplate broader engagement.

Accordingly, the name of the current initiative has evolved into ‘Fountain of Learning’, riding on a tide of enthusiasm for our aims and methods, among teachers, children and communities wherever we have been. We have been travelling far and wide from the windswept vastnesses of Changtang in the east, where our merest attention to local children was touchingly appreciated, to the lusher valleys of lower Ladakh, such as Tingmosgang, where we have brought new takes on education to the girl students of a local nunnery.

In addition to reading and pedagogical materials, we refurbish and repair their existing spaces, have conducted several educational workshops, teacher training and volunteering programmes. We are keen to expose the children to other forms of mental and spiritual development, especially the creation and appreciation of music and art, and hope to invite contributors in these fields to share their craft and creative joy with the children of the mountains.

More time spent in local schools has also deepened our insight into local needs. In particular, using the varied resources of educators and enthusiasts across India to develop and enhance teacher training in Ladakh is now a firm ambition. Even if we are not able to benefit every school and village directly, the evolution of a varied programme of skills and enthusiasm diffusion for local teachers may bring all kinds of positive outcomes into their lives.

The response so far has been delightfully encouraging, with individuals and contributors of many kinds coming forward to support us.



HOW YOU CAN HELP
FoL aspires to build in an organic way, an integrated network of like-minded individuals that can extend their support through care, love, time, effort, their skills or monetary means. We’ve achieved a great deal in the last four years with some amount of funding and some without any external support. However, lack of resources is restricting what we can do. As this is a long-term project we’d ideally love to raise 25,000 USD per annum but even 15,000 USD will already help us reach more children and those who work with them. For the year 2015, we require funding for the following. 
We have split them into 5 separate categories:
The first $ 3000 shall enable us to conduct 10 teacher training workshops 
The second $ 3000 shall help us invest in the co-ordination, training and cover costs involved in our volunteer programme.
The third $ 3000 shall be utilised to purchase beautiful books, educational toys, handcrafted dolls, stationery & art supplies.
The fourth $ 3000 shall enable us to cover operational costs of running the project, logistics, transportation, office expenses, printing, communication, stationery, overheads, etc.
The fifth $3000 will enable us to translate, publish 5 childrens' books for the year 2016. This hopefully shall also include shipping costs to Leh.

WHAT MORE CAN YOU DO
The largest challenge we have is reaching enough people.

Please do help us by writing emails to your friends and family, asking them to donate or spread the word.

Please post our campaign anywhere and everywhere you can – we only have 30 days to get to our target!

THANK YOU..



                                               

The Avalokitesvara Trust is registered under Bombay Public Charitable Trust Act, 1959.  Registration no. 19877

Sourcing and collection of children's books and setting up reading rooms The books are carefully selected by the team according to suitability for Ladakhi children. These include 3 levels of reading based on age-group and ability. So far from our base in Leh, we have set up 40 reading rooms and book corners in schools and learning centres, stocking them with a range of materials, mostly childrens' books, in all the languages taught here - Hindi, Urdu, English and Ladakhi/Tibetan. Some books are also bilingual (English-Hindi). The reading rooms are set up in existing schools, repainted and refurbished with furniture designed by us in traditional style primarily reading desks and shelves.

Implementing health and hygiene modules Children here are prone to respiratory, skin and bone problems due to the dry cold climate in Ladakh. There is a lack of hygiene awareness and facilities. We conduct fun and friendly modules for children which educate them in basic hygiene and its importance. 

Pedagogical material, educational games and sports equipmentThese include mathematical kits for pre-primary and primary schools that introduce number operations and logical abilities to the students, flash cards and language aids to assist effective learning in our reading programmes. Our volunteers have conducted football, yoga and physical awareness modules and also distributed equipment for sports and outdoor games.

Empowering Ladakhi teachers with educational resources, teaching aids and training programs One of our long term goals is to introduce and empower local teachers with ideas, methods and resources to encourage creative and experience-based learning, expanding the focus beyond curricular rote-learning. This is done through both organised workshops and the gradual building of a personal network of trained volunteers and interested teachers.

Translating and publishing childrens' books We are interested in publishing translations of select childrens’ books in local languages. Our first is a Ladakhi translation of ‘Chuskit goes to School’, in collaboration with Pratham Books. 
Volunteer Programme We orient and train volunteers with a structured pedagogy. They are appointed to teach children and train teachers at schools with these approaches to learning in the area of language, arts and maths. You can read the experiences shared by the volunteers here







                                



                      



FoL is a slow labour of dedication and love that has brought me deeper insights into their lives and while ‘educating,’ I have learnt and unlearnt a lot from them. Filling a classroom with love and connection, safety and trust, enthusiasm and the joy for learning encourages children to tap into their true creative potential. If we are to ignite young minds and a play a role in moulding them into self-confident, mindful and sensitive beings, let us do this gradually, with gentle encouragement and with the freedom to enjoy their childhoods. Each and every child, irrespective of his or her family or financial background, deserves a chance to go to school, to read and write, to explore, to discover and to learn, play and grow; while truly enjoying the process of learning! And it is said that where compassion thrives, so does learning!
-Abhigya Shukla Akester 
Founder & Director, Avalokitesvara Trust   





THE IMPACT AND IT'S IMPORTANCE
Children in remote areas of Ladakh are not receiving adequate support towards an enriching learning experience. Many schools do not have proper facilities, let alone a library. These children miss out on learning opportunities that can open them up to the world outside the mountainous terrain they live in. This project aims to offer an opportunity to these children who otherwise have been neglected.

The project supports existing private, government, monastic schools and learning centres by developing better facilities and supplies imperative for the efficient running of these schools. These facilities include creating reading rooms, volunteer programmes, conducting periodic educational and teacher training workshops. We further seek to support these needy schools with necessary educational, recreational, medical, sports and other relevant support.

Since
its
inception in
2011, the
project has expanded swiftly and naturally, in response to the widespread need,
and positive reception of our earlier work. From
beginnings
in one or two monastery schools, with the aim of enhancing educational
resources and experiences for the children of Ladakh, the project has reached
out to a much larger number of schools of all kinds across the region, and
begun to contemplate broader engagement. 
Accordingly,
the name of the current initiative has evolved into ‘Fountain of Learning’,
riding on a tide of enthusiasm for our aims and methods, among teachers,
children and communities wherever we have been. We have been travelling far and
wide from
the windswept vastnesses
of Changtang
in the east, where our merest attention to local children was touchingly
appreciated, to the lusher valleys of lower Ladakh, such as Tingmosgang,
where we have brought new takes on education to the girl students of a local
nunnery.
In
addition
to reading and
pedagogical materials, we refurbish
and repair their existing spaces, have
conducted
several educational workshops, teacher training and volunteering programmes.
We are
keen to expose the children to other forms of mental and spiritual development,
especially the creation and appreciation of music and art, and hope
to
invite contributors in these fields to share their craft and creative joy with
the children of the mountains. 
More
time spent in local schools has also deepened our insight into local needs. In
particular, using the varied resources of educators and enthusiasts across
India to develop and enhance teacher training in Ladakh is now a firm ambition.
Even if we are not able to benefit every school and village directly, the
evolution of a varied programme
of skills and enthusiasm diffusion for local teachers may bring all kinds of
positive outcomes into their lives. 
The
response so far has been delightfully encouraging, with individuals and
contributors of many kinds coming forward to support us.




HOW YOU CAN HELP
FoL aspires to build in an organic way, an integrated network of like-minded individuals that can extend their support through care, love, time, effort, their skills or monetary means. We’ve achieved a great deal in the last four years with some amount of funding and some without any external support. However, lack of resources is restricting what we can do. As this is a long-term project we’d ideally love to raise 25,000 USD per annum but even 15,000 USD will already help us reach more children and those who work with them. For the year 2015, we require funding for the following. 
We have split them into 5 separate categories:

The first $ 3000 shall enable us to conduct 10 teacher training workshops 


The second $ 3000 shall help us invest in the co-ordination, training and cover costs involved in our volunteer programme.


The third $ 3000 shall be utilised to purchase beautiful books, educational toys, handcrafted dolls, stationery & art supplies.


The fourth $ 3000 shall enable us to cover operational costs of running the project, logistics, transportation, office expenses, printing, communication, stationery, overheads, etc.


The fifth $3000 will enable us to translate, publish 5 childrens' books for the year 2016. This hopefully shall also include shipping costs to Leh.




WHAT MORE CAN YOU DO

The largest challenge we have is reaching enough people.

Please do help us by writing emails to your friends and family, asking them to donate or spread the word.
Please post our campaign anywhere and everywhere you can – we only have 30 days to get to our target!
THANK YOU..


                                               
The Avalokitesvara Trust is registered under Bombay Public Charitable Trust Act, 1959.  Registration no. 19877

story:
About Us 

In September 2014, our Founder, Amber Amour was sexually assaulted and like millions of others, her case was thrown out by the NYPD. Three days after her assault, she began doing chalk art to educate the masses about rape culture & consent and since its inception, millions of people from around the world have seen #StopRapeEducate  chalk art.

Today we have supporters who have started chalking all over the world and so far we have made it to: Australia, France, Canada, Sweden, Scotland, Italy, England, Hong Kong, New Caledonia, Tokyo, and Indonesia. 
Rape is a global issue and with your help, Amber Amour will take the #StopRapeEducate campaign around the world and back for our official World Tour! 

Travel Costs

Air, train, and/or bus transportation to the following cities:
  • 9/21- London
  • 9/28- Berlin
  • 10/5- Paris
  • 10/14- Madrid
  • 10/20- Johannesburg
  • 11/1- Capetown
  • 11/17- Singapore
  • 11/29- Sydney
  • 12/10- Tokyo
  • 12/15- Los Angeles
  • 12/20-  Atlanta
The total travel fare:  $3,450 
Low-cost accommodation: $350
Art Supplies: $200
Travel Expenses: $1000

Our Legacy

We've been busy! In less than a year #StopRapeEducate has made a strong impact and here are just a few ways:

  • Completed over 300 art pieces in NYC 
  • Left our mark in chalk at several U.S. colleges including Yale, Columbia, New York University, and Brooklyn College
  • Provided Counseling Services for survivors
  • Implemented educational curriculum in primary & secondary schools to create a culture of consent

Don't Forget...

Every donation matters! Ask your friends, family, community organizations, and place of worship to contribute!

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute, you can still help! Here are a few ways:

  • Share our campaign with your networks
  • Follow us on social media to stay updated
  • Send us positive vibes during this journey

story:
Short Summary

  • As an association of parents we are committed to providing our children the opportunity to learn close to their home. In 2011, when the local authorities closed the public school in our area, we opened a non-public school in the same building. Now the local government wants to use this building for a different purpose.
  • The only way to save our school is to buy the school building from the local government
  • Our school is not only a center of learning, but also a meeting place where the local community can experience culture and socialize.

What We Need 

    • We are raising money to buy the school building and to renovate it. We need $ 60 000
    • If we do not reach our entire goal, we will put the money in a bank account and continue to seek funds from other sources until we collect enough money to buy the school building.

The Impact

Our teachers are young, dedicated and passionate educators who use creative and innovative teaching methods.  We have a school garden where children grow seeds and we also teach sign language. Our students feel safe and happy in our non-public primary school in Ręków. We are one of the few educational institutions in Poland that supports and encourages homeschoolers through various activities and events. In this year’s national  curriculum test for sixth-graders our students scored 7 out of 9 in core subjects, which ranks us well above the nationwide average, and 9 out of 9 in English language, which ranks us as among the top primary schools in our country in this subject.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t afford to support us financially we would be very grateful if you could help us by spreading the word about this campaign among your friends. 

"The Active" website (sorry, only in Polish): http://www.stowarzyszenie-aktywni.pl/

story:
Hi, my name is Gary Bogle. I'm trying to raise $3,000 ($2,200 for accommodation and meals and the other $800 for my round trip flight to the Dominican Republic). I graduated from Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey, New Brunswick Campus. My major was Spanish, I specialized in translation and I minored in Latin American Studies. I recently came back from Spain this past weekend where I had the opportunity to teach English for 5 months, from January to May. It was a phenomenal experience. Not only was I able to grow professionally but spiritually as well.

During my last year at Rutgers University is where I met The Art of Living organization, which in short promotes meditation, yoga and breathing techniques to relieve stress. This organization has had a tremendous impact on my development as an individual as well as my wellbeing. As a youth growing up I have always been interested in interpersonal topics, things that deal with people. At that time I did not believe anything else mattered in the world other than people. And currently I have realized that life is all-inclusive and everything animate and inanimate is just as equally important as human beings. I have also learned that what I care about and always have cared about as a youth is human wellbeing. Exploring and learning about the Indian culture has taught me this. Therefore, I would like to play my part in the world by helping our youth realized it is crucial that they began to look inward. Not up or out but in is the only way out, quoting Sadghguru who owns Isha Foundaton. This foundation is very similar to The Art of Living.

I’ve been interested in becoming a volunteer yoga teacher since my first course with The Art of Living, last year May in 2014. And I would hate to miss out on this amazing opportunity to help teach our youth life oriented skills, like how to sit and breath, because I cannot afford to pay for the course. I believe it does not make any sense feeding children large of amounts of information, especially if they are not capable of sitting still and paying attention to the teacher's lesson. Not to mention, the way are education system works testing and grading are children only stresses them out and teaches them to worry. By adding organizations like The Art of Living to the curriculum we give are children a way to not only recuperate after a stressful week of exams but techniques that help them deal with things they may deal with at home. Especially children like me that comes from a minority background, where things are not always sweet. Where parents unintentionally put their stress and worries on their children, while passing down their bad habits like smoking and drinking.

Well, I am going to stop there. As one may have noticed I am highly passionate about the way we are raising are future generations. Therefore, in the far future I will dedicate myself to teaching and have a great impact on the administration of education.

story:
Entrance to Restoration

The historic buildings at the Arizona State Fairgrounds need your help. Maintenance and renovation are needed, but in order to do that properly, complete sets of measured drawings are needed, as the originals have been lost. Some of the buildings were constructed under the Works Progress Administration (WPA) of the New Deal program.

Local materials were combined with cutting edge technology. Several of the buildings have adobe walls with Lamella truss roofs, the same structural system used on the Wellington bomber in WW2.

Measured drawings were traditionally created by hand using lots of ladders. They followed standards set by the Historic American Building Survey, another New Deal program. Today, such an undertaking on these buildings would take months. Using modern technology of lasers, we will be laser scanning the buildings in under one week. Drones will be used to capture the details out of sight. For example, the roof of the Grandstand has an arrow painted on it. That arrow originally was used to help point pilots in the direction of the Phoenix airport. We want to capture and preserve this aspect of our Region’s history.


GG George, President of the Encanto Citizens Association talks about the project.

Requirements and Perks of the Job

To complete the project from scanning to drawings in hand, we need $42,000. Our local community has already raised $7,000. Your contribution will enable us to capture the data, but will have longer value in that with the drawings in hand, the State Fairgrounds can begin much needed maintenance and also apply for State and Federal funding to restore these iconic buildings.  

         

The drawings will also be submitted to the Library of Congress for preservation and a lasting heritage for generations to come.

*All contributions go to the Arizona Preservation Foundation

With any contribution you will receive a part of Arizona history.  The restoration project will be well documented and we would like to share the in the joy by providing a link to a documentary video. We will also send an electronic copy of a photo of the project autographed by the team members.

At the $500 level we will add actual electronic architectural HABS (Historic American Building Survey) drawings of one of the Fairground buildings.  


If you would like to have your name engraved on a brick that is used in the restoration project, we will be happy to provide that opportunity at $1000 contribution. This also includes the HABS Architectural Drawing of a building, autographed photo and the documentary video.

If you would like to contribute $5000, we would love to send you a 3D printed model keepsake of the building of your choice.  We will also provide the HABS Architectural Drawings to all of the buildings.  We will customize our documentary video to include your name or organization in the credits along with a personal message from the restoration team.  


You have an Impact

*Congratulations to our Team Leader Dr. Lauren Allsopp who just received the 2015 Governors Heritage Preservation Honor Award.   

TOPA 3D has an impact...Here's the team a Besthq Business Expo


Any contribution will help save the Arizona State Fairgrounds Historic Buildings.  We greatly value and welcome any amount that you can provide.

*All contributions go to the Arizona Preservation Foundation

story:
Namaste!

We need your help to finance the training and full-time salary of a new Entrepreneurship Development Facilitator for Nepal.

Your contribution will help us give free, real-time, international-standard assistance to hundreds of budding entrepreneurs in one of the poorest countries in the world.   

                           

Have you ever had an idea that you KNEW would make a great business?  What if you really wanted to try out your idea but had no experience?  Who would you talk to?  What if you couldn't afford the business counseling and training that was available?  Millions of enterprising people around the world share these concerns every day.  Many of them are too poor to pursue their ideas, and their dreams for a better life eventually fade. 

Now, people in  Nepal will get a real chance at seeing their entrepreneurship ideas become a reality through Himalayan Aid's Entrepreneurship Development Facilitation program.  

Entrepreneurship Development Facilitation helps individuals understand and realize their own dreams for personal growth. 

At the core of the program are the locally-chosen Entrepreneurship Development Facilitators, who live among, work with and chat with anyone who has ever considered starting a business and is in need of information.  They walk the village streets, meet in homes, in coffee houses, and generally make themselves visible to those who want to better themselves through entrepreneurship. 

Entrepreneurship Development Facilitators are trained to listen to entrepreneurs self-evaluate their own business ideas and to determine the passions they have for their own personal business growth.  The Entrepreneurship Development Facilitator then searches a wide base of local network participants for individuals that can team with and help the entrepreneur realize those passions. Entrepreneurship Development Facilitation builds teams. 

The critical component is that this service is FREE to the entrepreneur and available for as long as a community chooses to keep an Entrepreneurship Development Facilitator in their midst. The Himalayan Aid model guarantees free and equal access for all.

HOW WE'LL SPEND YOUR CONTRIBUTION:

Himalayan Aid, a U.S. Non-profit 501(c)(3) organization and a Nepal-registered NGO will distribute the funding from this campaign. Your  U.S. TAX DEDUCTIBLE contributions will go directly to train and pay the full-time salaries of one  Entrepreneurship Development Facilitator for a period of two years.  

WHY NEPAL?

In September of 2014, James Rinaldi, Director of Himalayan Aid, invited noted expert Ernesto Sirolli of the Sirolli Institute to Kathmandu to give a series of talks on his Enterprise Facilitation method.  The talks were a huge success and Dr. Sirolli spent the week meeting with hundreds of individuals and entrepreneur-supporting groups throughout Kathmandu. 

The response from Nepal was eager and enthusiastic.  Now Himalayan Aid will build on this enthusiasm and bring a Nepal-specific entrepreneurship training program to groups eager for such a program.  We have spent the last 14 months listening and learning from Dr. Sirolli and have developed our own program that, while informed by his concepts, is singular, proprietary  and culturally specific to the Needs of Nepal.  We have added our 20 years worth of expertise and service to the people of Nepal and have developed specific international networking ideas and secondary facilitation techniques to supplement many of the popular Entrepreneurship Development Facilitation projects that don't  go far enough and are less involved with the entrepreneurs they serve.   

ONE MORE THING:

It has always been our firm belief that the best and most effective way to help people in need is by working problems and developing solutions from the ground up—one person at a time, if need be—and  as equals.  We have come to realize that our Western "expertise" can count for very little at the point of impact and, often, our perception of what is best for those in need is often quite different from the needs they express to us in person. Entrepreneurship  Development Facilitation embodies this philosophy. 

This program will send a message that locally-originated ideas need only our partnership and not our dominance in order to succeed. 

 Please help us with your contribution.  Send a message.


See you in the Himalayas this May.....








If you need a PayPal option, click on the "donate" link at www.himalayanaid.org      Check out all of the other cool things we do in Nepal while you're at it. 
 

(Nepal-based perks do not include international airfare and have no cash redemption value.  If you can't make it to Kathmandu, we'll work out an alternative for you. Everest trek and Everest Mountain flight can be arranged for anyone, but fees will apply for those not entitled under perk reward. We will consider any option that makes you happy. Contact us at himalayan.aid@gmail.com)

self-evaluate their own business ideas and to determine the passions they have for their own personal business growth.  The Entrepreneurship Development Facilitator then
searches a wide base of local network participants for individuals that can team with and help the entrepreneur realize those passions. Entrepreneurship Development Facilitation builds teams. The critical component is that this service is FREE to
the entrepreneur and available for as long as a community chooses to keep an
Entrepreneurship Development Facilitator in their midst. The Himalayan Aid model guarantees free and equal access
for all.
HOW WE'LL SPEND YOUR CONTRIBUTION:Himalayan Aid, a U.S. Non-profit 501(c)(3) organization and a Nepal-registered NGO will distribute the funding from this campaign. Your  U.S. TAX DEDUCTIBLE contributions will go directly to train and pay the full-time salaries of one  Entrepreneurship Development Facilitator for a period of two years.  

WHY NEPAL?

In September of 2014, James Rinaldi, Director of
Himalayan Aid, invited noted expert Ernesto Sirolli of the Sirolli Institute to
Kathmandu to give a series of talks on his Enterprise Facilitation method.  The talks were a huge success and Dr. Sirolli
spent the week meeting with hundreds of individuals and entrepreneur-supporting
groups throughout Kathmandu. The response from Nepal was eager and enthusiastic.  Now Himalayan Aid will build on this enthusiasm and bring a Nepal-specific entrepreneurship training program to groups eager for such a program.  We have spent the last 14 months listening and learning from Dr. Sirolli and have developed our own program that, while informed by his concepts, is singular, proprietary  and culturally specific to the Needs of Nepal.  We have added our 20 years worth of expertise and service to the people of Nepal and have developed specific international networking ideas and secondary facilitation techniques to supplement many of the popular Entrepreneurship Development Facilitation projects that don't  go far enough and are less involved with the entrepreneurs they serve.   
ONE MORE THING:
It has always been our firm belief that the best and most
effective way to help people in need is by working problems and developing
solutions from the ground up—one person at a time, if need be—and  as equals. 
We have come to realize that our Western "expertise" can count
for very little at the point of impact and, often, our perception of what is
best for those in need is often quite different from the needs they express to
us in person. Entrepreneurship  Development Facilitation embodies this philosophy. 
This program will send a message that locally-originated
ideas need only our partnership and not our dominance in order to succeed.  
 Please help us with your contribution. 
Send a message.See you in the Himalayas this May.....If you need a PayPal option, click on the "donate" link at www.himalayanaid.org      Check out all of the other cool things we do in Nepal while you're at it.  (Nepal-based perks do not include international airfare and have no cash redemption value.  If you can't make it to Kathmandu, we'll work out an alternative for you. Everest trek and Everest Mountain flight can be arranged for anyone, but fees will apply for those not entitled under perk reward. We will consider any option that makes you happy. Contact us at himalayan.aid@gmail.com)

story:
Thank you for reading our story.

We are phd students from Bosnia. Our aim is increasing risk management culture in our society.

Last year Bosnia and Herzegovina was hit by flood. A lot of citizens were hit, a lot of companies lost their stocks, market etc. 

Risk report from World Economic Forum for 2014, stated that one of most damaging risk were floods. We translated report to Serbian, Bosnian and Croatian languages and sent it to our academia (Universities, professors, students). For report look here.

With this Campaign, my colleagues and me wish to increase risk awareness culture in our society. Starting campaign we wish to promote ERP technology and to implement this in Bosnian company. 

We established think tank organization which is called Centre for Risk. Our findings, and thoughts we report: here and here

After roundtable in main city in Bosnia (Sarajevo, Banja Luka, Bijeljina, Mostar and Trebinje) our aim is to find local companies we will implement Enterprise Risk Management System. Everything we do, we do on voluntary basis.

We are collecting money for 5 round table in Banja Luka, Sarajevo, Mostar, Bijeljina and Trebinje. Each roundtable will have budget of  400$ approximately.

Cost are:

1. renting

2. local media coverage,

3. refreshment,

4. materials,

5. establishing contacts with local companies,

6. fuel costs etc.

Our target group is: 27.000 Bosnian Companies, 110.000 students and 9.000 professors.

Next activity is building and promoting our website and networking with domestic universities and domestic companies. After that we would have platform for cooperation between universities and companies for increasing risk awareness culture, creating new jobs, case studies from companies for students etc.


If you can donate we will finish our activity sooner, and improve our society, and companies in better way. Also you can share this story and became our partner in mission we have.

Finishing successfully this campaign this would be 1st successfully finished crowdfunding campaign from Bosnia and Herzegovina.

story:
Short Summary

St. Louis has a growing, passionate group of Bernie Sanders Supporters.  We want to have Sander's presence in every parade, festival and event.  We want Bernie Sanders yard signs in every yard and bumper stickers on every car.

  • STL4Bernie meets monthly 
  • Our objective is to make sure every St. Louisian knows who Bernie Sanders is and that everyone understands his platform
  • Your donation means Bernie Sanders gains exposure in St. Louis.

Please donate to Bernie Sanders directly as well:  www.berniesanders.com

STL4Bernie Members:

No funds will be spent without a vote.  

Other Ways You Can Help

Email stl4bernie@outlook.com if you'd like brochures, flyers, canvassing information.  We also have a media contact list if you'd like to email or mail letters to editors about Bernie Sanders.

Get the word out and make some noise about Bernie Sanders!

story:
Muse Me 

A Monthly Subscription Based Crate Service



The movers and shakers of this world have one common thread - they are fiercely creative. Establishing a creative practice has been proven through numerous studies to cultivate independent thinking, innovation, and higher self-esteem in individuals.  Unfortunately, with extreme budget cuts in the school system currently - the arts are rapidly disappearing from the standard curriculum. 
Our campaign was created to address that void with a monthly subscription based crate service - "Muse Me". 
We believe our crate of creativity is a promising solution in bringing creativity back into the lives of students. We also believe that creativity should extend into the home and workplace - because there is no age limit for creativity. 
That said, we will begin our business by offering two subscriptions - one for ages 12-18 and one for ages 18+. 
Each month, the subscriber will receive a new box inspired by a muse. For example,"The Calliope Box" will have everything you need to inspire you to write poetry and "The Polymnia Box" will have everything you need to create your own musical instruments. Each subscription will also have a code to register for an online class that is aligned with the theme of your monthly subscription.
Our plan is to expand from these two subscriptions in year one to offer a crate for younger children, the fan fiction community, and niche branded themes in year two.


How Can You Help?


We are in the planning stage for creating 200 beta boxes. We would be thrilled to have contributors test our product and give us critical feedback that we require to improve our service before it officially goes "live".

  • Through this campaign, we need to raise $20,000 to produce a beta run of "Muse Me" boxes.  Initially we will need to purchase products for the boxes at regular retail prices, but we are already beginning to form strategic partnerships that will allow us to include promotional products at a discounted rate in the near future. 

  • Your funding will allow us to create 200 beta boxes through our chosen distribution provider - Crate Joy - and will help us begin to market our service globally. 

  • Our test site is already up and running. You can visit it by clicking this link:  Muse Me Beta Site. 


  • We strongly believe we will meet our financial goal, but on the off chance that we fall short, your contribution will still allow us to produce a beta run of a limited number of boxes to contributors so we can still receive the feedback we are seeking to help us move forward and continue growing.

We are both strongly committed to bringing the arts back into homes, schools, and businesses. We recognize what a massive impact creativity can make in every single area of an individual's life and are thrilled to be offering a catalyst for creativity on a massive scale. We are also fortunate to have several talented people who are already working diligently to support our efforts. 


Other Ways You Can Help

If you like our idea, please help us spread the word by utilizing the share buttons on this campaign and make an impact through this Creative Revolution! 

Sign up to subscribe to our newsletter on our website, here: Newsletter

Follow us on our new Facebook Page: Muse Me - Facebook 

Visit our Beta Test Site for Muse Me: Muse Me - Beta Site

Suggest potential sponsors for our subscription service: Email

story:
In quaint Tipperary Hill of Syracuse, New York sits All Saints Elementary.  Its creation resulted from the closing of the neighborhood Catholic Schools and the desire of the community to retain faith-filled education for their children.  Now nearing it's tenth anniversary, the school has come far - many of it's first students have graduated high school at the top of their classes and enrollment continues to rise.  The wonderful staff works hard to  give the students the very best education and a warm, caring community has developed around the school.  To support the school the parents, staff and surrounding community hold a variety of fundraisers to pay operating costs and keep tuition affordable to the average family. 

The desire now is to update our classrooms to provide our student's with access to 21st century instructional technology.  The building our school is housed in is rented and provides no technology support.  One step in this direction would be the installation of a Smart Board in every classroom, however, their high cost has been prohibitive up to this point.  We would like to start with raising funds to purchase one Smart Board and computer for one of our classrooms and continue to add boards until all 8 of our classrooms have them.  Any additional funds raised from this campaign would be applied to the next board purchase. Please donate to this wonderful school so that each student here has access to the many wonderful learning opportunities these boards would provide in our classrooms. 

Thank you!
All Saints Elementary of Tipperary HIll

Read our full story below:

In Tipperary Hill of Syracuse, New York, a group of parents and teachers came together and created something wonderful in the summer of 2006.

Faced with the prospect of losing the school they loved, and being told “No” every time they had an idea to try and save it, they decided to start their own independent school. The odds were definitely against them. It was nearly June when they decided to go for it. Ideally, you would want a year to plan something like this; to develop a business plan, to study other independent schools, to put together a staff, to recruit students, to find a location and fill it with the materials needed, etc….

They realized though, they could not wait. Students from four area schools were being forced to find new homes in September – and once they had adjusted to these new schools they were not likely to do it all over again the following year. So this group, armed with little experience but boundless passion, had to create an entirely new school in less than 100 days. And they did it.  Fast forward to today.  Now stands All Saints Elementary of Tipperary Hill, continuing forward with slow but steady growth and we refuse to raise tuition to the outlandish amounts other private schools charge – fully understanding the sacrifices parents are making to send their children to a faith-based school. (No, we can’t officially call ourselves a Catholic school, but we pray just the same as they do.)

Our commitment to providing an affordable, quality education to the children of the area remains the focus of all that we do. We are proud to be independent. We are All Saints.

story:
The purpose of this crowdfunding campaign is simple. An event, due to take place in Berlin on September 5th, had to be cancelled at the last minute. We'd hoped to donate 100% of the proceeds from this show to refugees in Berlin, and remain disappointed to have been unable to do that. Further, there was so much online outrage expressed at the fact this money wasn't raised that we want to facilitate these individuals still giving their 4-6€ (or more) to the cause.  

If Facebook indications were correct and 50 people attended, paying an average of 5€ each (the entrance was a 4-6€ sliding scale), then we would have generated 250€ in total. With this crowdfunding campaign, however, we would like to aim for double. Why? Only those in close proximity to the show could attend, but via the internet so many more people can participate. We believe that aiming to receive 5€ from 100 people doesn't seem far-fetched.

Why refugees?

There are so many answers to this question! Germany expects to receive a record 800,000 refugees and asylum seekers this year, which would be more than the entire EU continent combined in 2014. Unfortunately the danger and difficulties don't stop when the refugees reach Germany. Without the ability to obtain housing due to financial or legal restrictions (in addition to racial discrimination) they are placed in huge isolated camps in places like Brandenburg, with no access to shops or other people. For many individuals, especially women, queer and trans people, and those with children, the situation is often unbearable. These places are extremely unsafe, with at least 340 attacks taking place on refugee camps in Germany this year alone. These attacks are fueled by radical right-wing and anti-immigrant sentiment, including vandalism, hate speech and arson, as well as violent attacks on people. Further to this, however, with winter approaching many refugees will struggle in the inadequate conditions.

Further informative articles on the situation can be found on the respective Guardian, Collidoscope and BBC websites.

What is a Soli-Zimmer?

The literal translation is "soli room", which is when someone makes a room in their home available free of charge, typically to refugees and those seeking asylum. The idea behind a Soli-Zimmer isn't new. In fact, in cities like Berlin it has been ongoing for many years, but with gentrification taking a hold and rent rising for everyone, it has become a lot harder for people to make available a room for free in their WG. The result? Where there once existed a pool of Soli-Zimmern, there now exists very few, each of which is placed under continual and critical demand. 

There are, of course, added benefits to housing refugees, the main one being: integration. Many refugees have little hope of returning home, in some instances being completely unable to because their countries are engulfed by endless conflict or, more often, because they fear persecution if they were to return. Integrating into the local community of their host country offers them the opportunity of starting a new life, and whilst a complex and gradual process, it can be achieved with our help. To welcome refugees is about more than stickering walls and waving flags; it's about physically welcoming them into our homes and communities. It's about sharing a drink or a meal with them. It's about listening to their stories, and telling them yours. It's about making them feel safe and secure, warm and wanted.

Where does the money go?

Every single cent of the money raised through this crowdfunding platform will faciliate us paying the rent and relevant bills for (an as yet undetermined number of) refugees. The average all inclusive rent per room in Berlin is between 300-400€ per calendar month, with the exact amount being determined by both location and size (of room). The more "desirable" the location and larger the room, the more expensive; but whilst location isn't an especially important factor when housing refugees, size of room is. The larger the room the greater the chance of keeping family members or friends together, without resulting in either discomfort or forced separation. 

Remember: 300€ covers only one room for one month, and therefore even if we were to reach 500€ with this campaign, we'd be struggling to house someone for two months. In combination with other initiatives, we would like to generate 1.200€ to cover rent from November through to the end of February, i.e. the worst of the winter months. Obviously if our funding is surpassed on Indiegogo, or via our other initiatives, then we will either be able to house more people during the winter months, or the same people for longer.

Unable to contribute?

If you're unable to participate, either financially or through this online medium, don't worry! There are other ways to help us achieve our goal:

- share this Indiegogo campaign through your email contacts or social media, in the hope of reaching those who can donate online

- if you live in Berlin, perhaps participate in one of our other initiatives, such as our regular monthly Refugee Support Soli-KüFA, or one of the two Refugee Support Soli-Abends scheduled for September 10th and September 17th

There are in fact countless ways to help the refugees who arrive in your community, and we are in the process of working on an infographic detailing this. Once complete we will circulate it at a later date. 

Note: Indiegogo takes 5% of the total amount raised, so for each 5€ contribution we lose 25c. It might not seem like much, but it will soon add up to a hefty amount. If you are able to cover this fee, please consider amending your donation to take this into consideration. 

Love and rage! xo
