story:
Summary

During a visit to Danai Children’s Home in Harare, Zimbabwe in 2012 my family and I hosted a pizza party for the children and staff at the orphanage. We gave out books, clothes and shoes that we had collected from friends in the United States. It was heartwarming experience with the children, seeing the smiles on their faces, and their eagerness to show us around their home. During a tour of the home, I held a 2 month old boy and asked if he would be adopted soon. The director of the home explained that due to cultural taboos, this little boy would most likely spend his first 18 years of life in the orphanage. Thereafter, he would have to leave and support himself.

Access to education while living at the orphanage is not guaranteed, some children will leave the orphanage without graduating from high school. Without a basic education and financial or family support these young children are doomed to an adulthood filled with poverty and or crime.

Driving away from the orphanage that day, we felt an intense sadness and helplessness. We questioned the impact of our visit. The children would soon outgrow the clothes, the ink in the pens and markers would soon dry out, and their future would still be bleak.

I shared my experience with friends who had at some point expressed their desire to make a real difference. Five of us came together to form an organization that would seek to educate and empower vulnerable children like the ones at the orphanage.

We strongly believe that education is a great equalizer and will ultimately be the tool to help realize their potential. One of our favorite African proverb that states:

“If you want to go fast, go alone. If you want to go far, go together.” – Unknown

We cannot do this alone .We need your help to accomplish the great task of educating and empowering these children. This is one gift that could change the course of their life. Your assistance towards the funding of their tuition is a priceless investment in their future.

“Give a man a fish, feed him for a day. Teach a man to fish, feed him for a lifetime.” ― Confucius

What We Need

Here is some important information about your donation:

  • 100% of your donation goes directly to education costs for 12 children at Danai Children's Home.
  • Primary school tuition breakdown for 12 children: 
                   US$90 (tuition) x 3 semesters x 12 children=US$3,240

*We are happy to share records and proof that all funds raised will be used for the sole purpose of funding the tuition costs for these children. 

The Impact

Did you know that in Zimbabwe:

  • Nearly one out of three children is malnourished. In addition, many Zimbabwean children lack access to basic education, health care and daily essentials for survival. 
  • School enrollment is highest in first grade, but first graders also have the high dropout rates. In 2009, three percent of children in first grade left school.
In response to these and other challenges, we believe we can help. This year we have the ambitious goal of sending 12 orphans from the Danai Children’s home to Primary school. Please consider donating to help support early learning opportunities to give the children of Zimbabwe a brighter future.


 Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that you may not be able to contribute financially, but that doesn't mean you can't help.

  • Please help us get the word out and make some noise about this campaign.
  • You can use the Indiegogo share tools or visit uswebsite!
#tembaforourchildren

story:
Short Summary

I'll be flying to Kathmandu on May 23, 2015. Trying to raise funds for children who're in desperate need of aid. Please assist every $1 counts. 

What We Need & What You Get

I am hoping to raise $20,000 to donate to the children for basic survival needs, and finding homes or placement into orphanages.

The Impact

I wish to give as many children as possible, who have lost their parents and homes,  the support they require by assisting with their basic necessities.

Other Ways You Can Help

A donation of any amount will help in many ways.  And sharing my cause with family and friends would greatly benefit the innocent children of Nepal.  Nepal thanks you for your support.

story: Hallo!
story_txt: Hallo!

story:
Hi!

First let me say, I know, I said in the video: "Georgia, ...and other cities" -- hey, you know what I meant, bruh.
More money raised = more billboard rentals.  We've done this before, so we've learned from our mistakes.  We look for inexpensive rentals that will have the most impact.
The 9/11 Truth Movement does a lot of 'preaching to the choir'.  This campaign is a way to get the word out to folks who don't know the truth, don't know much about it, or think it's a done deal.  Good things are happening in the movement, but we've got to let folks know about the basics and that we are alive and stronger than ever.
Please contribute however you can.  Give till it hurts!  Get the word out to your friends and friends you haven't met yet via social media.
For those who already know 9/11 Truth, please ask them to get a banner and be a FOT (FACE OF TRUTH): http://iamthefaceoftruth.com/ 
For folks who don't know 9/11 Truth, please use your best source and share it with them.  My personal favorites are "9/11 Experts Speak Out: Explosive Evidence" or David Hooper's "Anatomy of a Great Deception".
As for the faces on the billboards, we pick out active FOT folks who have a picture that will be easy to see from the road.  Personally, I think it's much better if the person shows their face without sunglasses.  We will show faces with sunglasses, but if you can provide another photo without them, that'd be super dooper.
If you'd like to give out flyers near a billboard, that'd be AWESOME!!  Please contact me via the FOT Facebook page.
Thank you very much for checking us out, and again if you have contributed or plan to do so.  Not a cent is wasted.  It all goes to renting billboards.
Namaste.
Mike

story:
What is PROJECT WHY ?

Project WHY is an NGO who tries to help slum children by giving them a better education support.

It opened its firstclass in 2000 only with 40 children who'd never gone school. Today, Project Why has become a beautiful family that brings together different parts of India, different social and economic strata of society, different forms of worship and faith under one invisible roof big enough to hold everyone together. Today, the organisation reaches out 1056 Children in 5 different Centers located in Delhi slums (At Okhla, Giri Nagar, Madanpur Khader, Govindpuri and since April 2015, onenear to the Yamuna River).

More than that, Project Why is more than a help for children. Its objectives are deeper. We try to break barriers - be they caste or social status, and make Project Why a true reflection of an ideal India. We empower the community to take on their own responsibility and show them how to find solutions within their existing context. 

Why do we ask your help ?

Project Why needs your help to keep the doors of its « Special section » open. Located in the Govindpuri Centre, it is reserved to disabled children and young Adults with special needs.

This Section is essential : It allows these people to live with dignity, to be more independant, and in some cases find their vocation. In India, It is a necessity. Indeed, Disabled people have practically no option within the social system. We are trying to ensure that our students remain integrated within their family and community.

Facts about the Special Section

The running cost of this centre, per month, is 52 000 RS (approximately 700 euros) - for 17 children (12 boys and 5 girls) from 6 to 49 years old. In the special Section of Project Why, from 9 Am to 4 Pm, Children can find a space where they can both escape for a few hours every day and laugh to their heart's content and also a way to keep their ability in mind. Children are taught self-care and basic living skills such as bathing, washing clothes, basic cooking, shopping... 

But above all the daycare centre is a fun filled place where all children are taught computers, dance and many other recreational activities. However we are aware of the reality on the ground and the fact that for some the future remains bleaks and we need to find a long-term alternative.

How will your contribution help the "Special Section" ?

That explains why we are asking you for your help. If we can keep the Special Section open, these differently-abled students can retain a roof on their heads, and lead their lives with self-respect and dignity. Your contribution will go directly towards maintenance and upkeep of this section. Indeed, it will help us to create activities suited to the abilities and needs of these students. In your hands, you have the power to ensure some income generation for each one of them, hence assuring that they retain a roof on their heads, even after the demise of their parents.
story_txt:
What
is PROJECT WHY ? 



Project
WHY is an NGO who tries to help slum children by giving them a better education support. 



It
opened its firstclass in 2000 only with 40 children who'd never gone school. Today, Project Why has become a beautiful family that brings
together different parts of India, different social and economic
strata of society, different forms of worship and faith under one
invisible roof big enough to hold everyone together. Today, the
organisation reaches out 1056 Children in 5 different Centers located
in  Delhi slums (At Okhla, Giri Nagar, Madanpur Khader, Govindpuri
and since April 2015, onenear to the Yamuna River).

More
than that, Project Why is more than a help for children. Its objectives are deeper. We
try to break barriers - be they caste or social status, and make
Project Why a true reflection of an ideal India. We empower the
community to take on their own responsibility and show them how to
find solutions within their existing context. 


Why
do we ask your help ? 


Project Why needs your help to keep the doors of its « Special section » open. Located in the Govindpuri Centre, it is reserved to disabled children and young Adults with
special needs. 

This Section is essential : It allows these people to live with dignity,
to be more independant, and in some cases find their vocation. In India,
It is a necessity. Indeed, Disabled people have practically no option
within the social system. We are trying to ensure that our students remain integrated within their family and community.


Facts about the Special Section 



The
running cost of this centre, per month, is 52 000 RS (approximately 700 euros) - for 17 children
(12 boys and 5 girls) from 6 to 49 years old. In the special Section
of Project Why, from 9 Am to 4 Pm, Children can find a space where
they can both escape for a few hours every day and laugh to their
heart's content and also a way to keep their ability in mind.
Children are taught self-care and basic living skills such as
bathing, washing clothes, basic cooking, shopping... But above all
the daycare centre is a fun filled place where all children are
taught computers, dance and many other recreational activities.
However we are aware of the reality on the ground and the fact that
for some the future remains bleaks and we need to find a long-term alternative.


How will your contribution help the "Special Section" ?
That
explains why we are asking you for your help. If we can keep the Special Section open, these differently-abled students can retain a roof on their heads, and lead their lives with self-respect and dignity. Your contribution will go directly towards maintenance and upkeep of this section. Indeed, it will help us to create activities suited to the abilities and needs of these students. In your hands, you have the power to ensure some income generation for
each one of them, hence assuring that they retain a roof on their
heads, even after the demise of their parents.

story:
For twenty years the Louis Armstrong Middle School has been offering the opportunity for students to attend an astronaut-training program called Space Camp. 

Space Camp first opened its doors to the public in the spring of 1984 in Huntsville, Alabama. It quickly branched out to several locations including Florida, California, and even internationally, to Canada, Japan, and Turkey. For our first eight years we traveled to U.S. Space Camp in Florida. Due to budget cuts, all U.S. locations have ceased operations with the exception of the original Space Camp in Huntsville.

To help lighten the cost of our trip this year, I have decided to take our group back to Space Camp Canada in Montreal, Quebec. This will be our twelfth year attending Space Camp there. The Louis Armstrong Middle School is the only school in New York City to offer an opportunity of this magnitude to its students.

The trip takes place over four days at the end of March. We will be chartering a bus to take us to Montreal.

The trip takes place over four days at the end of March. We will be chartering a bus to take us to Montreal on aFriday and return on a Monday. The trip is open to all students in the fifth through eighth grades. Parent chaperones are needed to accompany us on the trip. Chaperones must be at least 21 years old. Our maximum capacity is 40 students and adults. ***All participants will need a valid U.S. passport to travel***

The tentative cost for this year’s trip will be approximately $750 per person. This includes all transportation, meals, program materials, a clothing package, and lodging at Space Camp. When compared with the cost of a trip to Huntsville, we will only be paying about one third the price. Your donation will help us offset the cost of this year's trip.


ABOUT SPACE CAMP

THE BASICS

Learn the history and principles of space propulsion and guidance systems and put your knowledge to good use when you and your team complete their mission. Historic achievement of manned space flights will be highlighted with a tour of the Cosmodome, Canada's largest museum dedicated to spaceflight.


ASTRONAUT and MISSION TRAINING

This is your chance to find out what it takes to be an astronaut - the academics, the emotion, and the physical rigors. The Zero "G" Wall gives would-be mission specialists an opportunity to work in a neutrally buoyant state. Step by step you'll build an ACCESS (Assembly Concept for Constructing an Erectable Space Structure) tower for a space station.

Up and over, head over heels is the direction you'll take in the Multi-Axis Trainer. This simulator is patterned after the earlier Project Mercury trainers, which conditioned the astronauts for possible disorientation due to tumbling in a flight emergency. Later, wearing a space suit, you will be busy repairing a satellite in a simulated environment.  Other simulation exercises include the 1/6th Gravity Chair and the 5 Degrees of Freedom (5DF) simulator.

Throughout the weekend, you will become familiar with the current Space Transportation System (STS), in preparation for your simulated shuttle mission. Finally, you and your team are divided into Orbiter and Mission Control crews. The countdown begins as you climb into the full scale Space Shuttle mock-up. Commander, pilot, mission specialists, and payload specialists - the orbiter crew keep in tight contact with the professionals at mission control from launch to landing. Teamwork and training are put to the test as you try to achieve your mission goals and bring the crew home safely.


SPACE TECHNOLOGY and the FUTURE

Explore living and working in space with simulated space station training featuring the Manned Maneuvering Unit (MMU) and Space Station Mobility Trainer (SSMT). Plus, with your teammates, you will fulfill the assignment of designing and building a spacestation model.

The benefits of future missions and extended space flight will be explored with an eye on industry, agriculture, and the environment. Practical uses for space programs will also be discussed.

story:
THE FUNDING TIME FOR THIS PROJECT HAS NOW ENDED BUT .... YOU CAN STILL CONTRIBUTE, EITHER THROUGH OUR WEBSITE OR THROUGH THE 'FRIENDS OF THE ISRAEL ANTIQUITIES AUTHORITY (a 501 c3 organization). FOR FULL DETAILS GO TO OUR WEBSITE.


"The Great Synagogue and the excavations are important not only for Lithuania, but for the global Jewish community. It is a powerful symbol of both a great Jewish heritage, a great tragedy when the entire Jewish community was destroyed, and it is a very powerful symbol for the Jewish future. … The Great Synagogue is not only about Jewish history, it is a particularly important element in Lithuania’s history of the colourful and multiethnic Vilnius."

Lithuanian Prime Minister Andrius Kubilius during his visit to the site of the Great Synagogue of Vilnius in 2011.

Website for the Great Synagogue of Vilna & Shulhoyf Project

Facebook page for the Great Synagogue & Shulhoyf Project


A Short Introduction to the Project

Though only a small fraction of the historic synagogues and other Jewish communal buildings  of Lithuania survived the Holocaust, they are an essential and integral part of the cultural heritage of Lithuania. None was more consequential or important than the magnificent Great Synagogue of Vilna (Vilnius), the oldest and most significant monument of Litvak Jewry. 

Sadly, like most of the edifices of Litvak culture, the Great Synagogue of Vilna was ransacked and destroyed. As part of the process to find a fitting memorial for the Synagogue and its associated buildings, we propose the creation of a joint expedition of Lithuanian, Israeli and American heritage professionals - archaeologists, historians, architects and other scholars, to excavate, preserve and present in-situ the remains of the Great Synagogue as part of an overall scheme for the long-lasting safeguarding of the memory of the Jewish community of Vilnius, the 'Jerusalem of Lithuania'.

The excavation of the Great Synagogue, as a joint project of Lithuanian and Israeli heritage professionals, presents an opportunity that goes far beyond the research possibilities that provide for a better understanding of the Great Synagogue and the surrounding structures of the shulhoyf. By working together, Lithuanians, Israelis and Litvaks from around the world, emphasis can be placed on the importance of Jewish built cultural heritage as an inseparable part of Lithuanian heritage that needs to be celebrated by all and preserved for perpetuity.

It is the hope of the team that the joint efforts of professionals, volunteers and funders of all communities, will meet in a joint project that can bring together the widely dispersed community of Lithuanians and Litvak Jews while preserving part of their mutual heritage for the future.


The Team and the Institutional Partnership

This project has the approval of the Department of Cultural Heritage under the Lithuanian Ministry of Culture and the support of the Jewish Community of Lithuania (Lietuvos Žydu Bendruomene), the Vilna Gaon Jewish State Museum and the History Faculty of Vilnius University. The highly experienced research team has worked on heritage projects around the world. The team consists of Dr. Jon Seligman and Architect Ram Shoef of the Israel Antiquities Authority, Zenonas Baubonis of the Kulturos paveldo išsaugojimo pajegos (Culture Heritage Conservation Authority of Lithuania), Prof. Mike Turner of the Bezalel Academy of Arts and Design, Dr. Vladimir Levin of the Centre for Jewish Art of the Hebrew University of Jerusalem, Prof. Prof. Richard Freund of the Maurice Greenberg Center for Judaic Studies, University of Hartford, Prof. Harry Jol of the University of Wisconsin, Eau Claire, Architect Tsila Zak and Prof. Philip  Reeder of Duquesne University.


How You can Contribute to the Great Synagogue and Shulhoyf of Vilna (Vilnius) Research Project

Here is the opportunity to become involved in this important and exciting project. Beyond the involvement in an important heritage project to recover part of the lost heritage of the Jews of Lithuania, the Litvaks, this project also provides the opportunity for many Jews of Litvak origin, to reconnect with their own history by helping to discover the remains of the most important monument of Litvak Jewry.

The successful outcome of the preliminary excavation of 2011 and the Ground Penetrating Radar survey in 2015, shows the potential of continued excavation at the site to uncover further sections of the Great Synagogue and the surrounding twelve synagogues, mikve (ritual bath) and communal buildings known as the Shulhoyf. The excavation will provide us with answers concerning the architecture of this important complex of buildings, while also exposing remains for future presentation. These, when appropriately conserved, can be integrated into an  architectural proposal for 'The Jewish Memorial Centre in Vilnius', in cooperation with Lithuanian Authorities, the Vilnius Municipality and the existing Lithuanian Jewish community, all with the aim of ensuring that Jewish built cultural heritage is seen as an importance and inseparable part of Lithuanian heritage that needs to be celebrated by all and preserved for perpetuity. 

As we have no institutional funding for this project, we are seeking help from you, the public. All help, of whatever amount, is appreciated. Full costing of the project cannot really be assessed at this early phase, so we are gathering the funds in stages. For the coming season of excavation at the site of the Great Synagogue in Vilnius in June 2016 we will need to raise around $30,000 to cover the costs of excavation, conservation, labour, travel, accommodation, research, publication and finds processing. Furthermore, if you are interested in participating in the excavation in Vilnius in June 2016, we are opening opportunities to volunteer for the excavation.


Naming Opportunities

The Great Synagogue & Shulhoyf of Vilna Project provides an intriguing naming opportunity. We are honoured to invite you to join us in this undertaking. It is with the help and support of our friends from around the world who strongly believe in the importance of our work, that our vision will become a reality for the benefit of present and future generations. Donors who wish will be listed on our website and their names will also be written for perpetuity in the publication volumes that will accompany our work.


A Community Vision - Bringing Lithuanians & Litvaks Together

The Great Synagogue and its associated buildings were the most important monuments of Lithuanian Jewry and a central part of the heritage of Vilnius and Lithuania. The tragic events of the twentieth century, that included the physical annihilation of the Jewish community of Vilnius and the destruction of its built cultural heritage, has left the city devoid of the major monuments that signified the place of the Jews in the culture and history of Vilnius.  The potential archaeological discovery of remains of both the structure of, and artifacts from, the Great Synagogue and of the buildings of the Shulhoyf, will provide a contribution to raising awareness of the role of Jews to the development, history and culture of Vilnius. It will also give material substance to future plans to perpetuate the memory of the Great Synagogue and the Jewish community as part of future plans to establish a fitting memorial at the site. 

After proper analysis of the quality and significance of the finds, due thought should be given to the integration of the finds in a proposal for a Jewish Memorial Centre in Vilnius to create an appropriate commemorative monument for the Great Synagogue, the Shulhoyf and the Jewish community of Vilnius at the site, an integral part of the World Heritage site of the Historic Centre of Vilnius. A future 'Jewish Memorial Centre in Vilnius' at the site of the Great Synagogueaims at preserving the memory of Lithuania's multicultural heritage through the establishment of a memorial to the Jewish cultural, communal and intellectual contribution and achievements to the history of the city. 

It is the hope of the team that the joint efforts of professionals, volunteers and donors of all communities, will meet in a joint project that can bring together the widely dispersed community of Lithuanians and Litvak Jews while preserving part of their mutual heritage for the future.


Full details on this project can be seen at our website and on Facebook

story:
About Jungle Books

Jungle Books is a space for people to enjoy a semblance of normality and take their minds off the difficuties they face living in the Calais jungle. 

In the library space, refugees can borrow books or study.  Artists do workshops and there are now laptops used for language Learning. but once we have wifi, they will also enable refugees to keep in contact with family and friends at home.  Your funding will help us finish  an extension which (even unfinished) is being used by musicians and even for yoga lessons.  We are planning to build a children's space where they can read, draw and play. 

Jungle Books is also a focal point for refugees to talk about their needs and funds raised will be used to continue the distribution of cooking kits (sturdy stoves and gas bottles to replace open fires) and mini-generators which are in great demand. 

What your money will be used for

Money raised will be used to run the project, expand to provide dedicated area for children and continue the work supplying vital equipment which makes the refugees lives easier. 

We are grateful for any support to enable the project to continue expanding and to continue providing a little bit of normality...

500€ can provide materials to build a children's space
100€ provides a safe cooking kit
100€ provides a mini-generator
...

Thank you for supporting us - and if you can't donate money please share...

story:
Baja Sae USB

Who are we?

BAJA SAE USB is a Venezuelan UNDERGRADUATE TEAM of the Universidad Simón Bolívar. Since 2005, this racing team BUILD an all-terrain vehicle that COMPETES each year in the United States against 100 universities, obtaining great achievements as first place in Design Presentation (2012), first place in Cost Presentation (2011) and the best Overall 14/120 (2008). Therefore, it forms integral PROFESSIONALS with technical and management skills. 

Why are we asking for help?

We are asking for help to BUILD our eleventh prototype, because of national companies cannot SUPPORT us with what we need. We had search for help by the usual means without getting good results because of the severe economic situation in our country. Besides, most of the materials and pieces we use are not available to purchase on our country.

Hence this difficult situation, we are asking for your HELP.

What kind of help are we asking?

Inicially, we are asking you to SHARE our project to your relatives and PROMOTE our campaign (Donate 20$ Find 40$ more, which consist on donating 20$ and get people to donate 40 $ in exchange of the logo of your brand, company or your name on our team shirts) to PARTICIPATE by eleven consecutive years and COMPETE  with engineering made in Venezuela. It is not difficult, by donating only 20$ that represents 0,22% of our final goal and 1000% of happiness to us.

You can also obtain BENEFITS such as: your brand logo on our official shirts and on the body of the prototype.

To BUILD our all-terrain prototype we need a lot of DEDICATION and PLANIFICATION; yet, the materials we need at the moment are: 

Shocks

http://atvgalaxy.com/fox-shocks-float-front.html 695$

all-terrain vehicle that COMPETES each

story:
Who We Are & What We're Doing!

We are a group of people with a shared understanding of the refugee situation in Turkey and abroad. Between us we are involved in a variety of social justice work, including refugee rights and support. We decided to act on our ideas; to put solidarity into practice.. but we need your support to make it happen!

Outline:
We are creating a flexible space that can meet the desires and needs of the people using it. This means that it can be a space for women to meet one day and can be a workshop for learning first aid or simply an evening meal on another. The space will not be issue-specific, meaning that if (somehow!) the situation of refugees in Izmir dramatically improves, the space will still be able to function as a healthy and vital place in Izmir. It is ultimately a community space by and for whoever uses it, with particular attention to refugees.

                                           



Why is Izmir significant for refugees?

Izmir is the one of busiest cities and transit routes to Europe for refugees in Turkey. The city is one of the key points of actual struggle. In the neighborhood of Basmane refugees are easily recognisable, walking the streets with their backpacks and black plastic bags containing their life jackets, for both adults and children. The need for refugee support in Izmir is huge. This cannot be overstated.

We are compelled to do more than simply provide food, water and other necessary items. We want to have a space where refugees and people in Izmir can be together, where people can share support and build relationships. We will encourage people themselves to support refugees, rather than support being something that others do. We will do it. The situation is urgent and it is important that refugees can organise for themselves!

Local Situation

The situation here in Izmir is intense, desperate and gets very little attention in Europe or anywhere, in fact. This is in spite of the reality that Izmir is a transit city for hundreds of thousands of refugees fleeing persecution. However, Izmir is not part of the 'designation system' for (non-Syrian) refugees (around 250,000 people) so huge groups of people live in the streets with little support. The 10 designated cities with camps hold a total of 300,000 people, painfully short for the 2.2 million people left to find themselves shelter.

Some refugees decide to stay in Izmir while most travel elsewhere, often continuing to nearby Greek islands. The risks of this are extremely high, many people drown, and face huge risks to their physical and mental health. On top of this, the economic cost of travelling is always above 1,000 euros, often multiple times this. However the impacts of war, persecution and poverty are so great that the costs, financially, emotionally, physically and psychologically are worth the risk in hopes of safety. People go to extreme lengths to get this money. So, that's a rough guide to the complex and harsh situation here.                                            

Action Plan

- We want to establish a safer space for children to play, to learn and, simply, to be.

- We plan to have a people's kitchen where people can share in the preparation of food, as well as eating healthy and tasty meals together.

- We will hold cultural events showcasing, for example, Syrian music artists. The motivations for such events include encouraging calming environments for people, sharing in artistic expression so that culture can help 'home' transcend the borders of nation states.

- We want to have language sessions, so that people can learn things that are practically useful, whether they are staying in Turkey or travelling, for example to Germany, England or France.

- We will create an infoshop to orient people to places, for example to places providing health supplies.

- We'll make, print and share pamphlets, for example "what is the legal situation of refugees, paperless or undocumented people in Turkey".

- We encourage discussion of possibilities, to reduce rushed decisions concerning high risk options. We do not seek to idealise Europe or any particular place, but rather support people in making informed decisions for themselves.


What We Need & How We'll Follow Through

We have set our target at £2,500 as we are ambitious to resource the initiative for the short-term first. Here is a breakdown of how we intend to spend the money you contribute:

  • £1,500 is required for rent and bills. We need a suitable space, with water, heating, bathroom, kitchen and open-space. We hope to raise enough money to secure us in rent for as many months as possible.
  • £500 is required for equipment and furniture. Although we are a very resourceful bunch and have a healthy network of local support, we will need to buy some items, likely including a cooker, a fridge, a washing machine (for people's clothes) and a variety of kitchen utensils. We also wish to have seating for as many people as possible.
  • £200 is desired for publicising our opening event, future events and also necessary information useful for refugees and local supporters. We'll be print pamphlets, flyers and hopefully a banner / sign above the door!
  • £300 is also desired for overheadeds - the things we do not yet foresee but which will require money to make happen.
We think you'll agree that it would be wasteful for us to send out individual items to each of our contributors and also we find it unfair that those with more money could get better gifts. Rather, we will be reporting on our progress and documenting how things are going throughout. We wish to make our efforts as transparent and public as possible. We will be thanking you all each time we make public statements and during refugee+local events! We want your money to go directly to where it is needed. No gimmicks and no waste!

What if we don't reach our goal?

Regardless of whether we reach our goal or not we are going to GO FOR IT! We want you to contribute the best you can and to work with us in publicising our efforts :) We of course hope we can far exceed our goals, both in terms of funding and in terms of expectations for the space!


                                    


The beginning! The launch!

SO, there you have it! We have big plans and big hopes that you'll do all you can to support us. We'd love for you to fund us as much as you possibly can, that will really help! For those who can't contribute financially, please support us by sharing our campaign, bring people to our Facebook, Twitter, share our YouTube+video. All of this will help draw others to us!

LET'S DO THIS!!!

story:
It's a harsh reality that 11.3 million children have to take care of themselves after the school day ends. Not surprisingly, the peak hours for juvenile crime and experimentation with drugs and alcohol are between three and six pm. After-school programs are critical to children and families today, yet the need for programs is far from being met. This is why we started The Guardian Project.

What is the Guardian Project?

Guardian is a 501(c)(3) non-profit that provides FREE after-school training in Brazilian Jiu Jitsu and boxing to Oakland's youth. We aim to provide at-risk youth with skills that help them build self esteem, confidence and discipline through martial arts. We want to prepare kids for the future by providing a world-class environment to connect with mentors, peers, and community leaders.

Our goal is to raise funds to give this gift to over 225 children in our first year.

The benefits of martial arts extend to and improve all aspects of life. Students gain the ability to focus, work hard, believe in themselves, and create a loving and welcoming community for others. Guardian provides a safe haven before and after training that includes desks, computers, and mentors for students. Mentors will aid students with their homework as well as teach passion projects such as video editing, web design, and other essential communication skills of today and tomorrow.

What have we done so far?

Joel and Ben have been working over the last 18 months nights and weekends outside of their full time careers at Twitter. They have put in their own money to date to fund all of legal and accounting, pre-payment of lease, first year insurance, starter equipment, and everything else to get Guardian to this point. They are not receiving any salary or financial compensation related to The Guardian Project.

What will we use the funds for?  

The donations will apply directly to covering the cost of our students’ membership. Although most commercial martial arts gym memberships can range from $125 to over $200 per month, we have been able to cost out a child's monthly fees at roughly $45. We have secured a beautiful space in downtown Oakland for the next five years and the doors have just opened as of December 14th for both kids and adults to begin training. This idea has become a reality with hard work and love. Now we need your help to make it a success.

#jointhefight

With your help, how many lives we can change for the better?

Twitter & Instagram - @guardiangym www.guardiangym.org

-Joel & Ben
story_txt: It's a harsh reality that 11.3 million children have to take care of themselves after the school day ends. Not surprisingly, the peak hours for juvenile crime and experimentation with drugs and alcohol are between three and six pm. After-school programs are critical to children and families today, yet the need for programs is far from being met. This is why we started The Guardian Project.What is the Guardian Project?Guardian is a 501(c)(3) non-profit that provides FREE after-school training in Brazilian Jiu Jitsu and boxing to Oakland's youth. We aim to provide at-risk youth with skills that help them build self esteem, confidence and discipline through martial arts. We want to prepare kids for the future by providing a world-class environment to connect with mentors, peers, and community leaders.Our goal is to raise funds to give this gift to over 225 children in our first year.The benefits of martial arts extend to and improve all aspects of life. Students gain the ability to focus, work hard, believe in themselves, and create a loving and welcoming community for others. Guardian provides a safe haven before and after training that includes desks, computers, and mentors for students. Mentors will aid students with their homework as well as teach passion projects such as video editing, web design, and other essential communication skills of today and tomorrow.What have we done so far?Joel and Ben have been working over the last 18 months nights and weekends outside of their full time careers at Twitter. They have put in their own money to date to fund all of legal and accounting, pre-payment of lease, first year insurance, starter equipment, and everything else to get Guardian to this point. They are not receiving any salary or financial compensation related to The Guardian Project.What will we use the funds for?  The donations will apply directly to covering the cost of our students’ membership. Although most commercial martial arts gym memberships can range from $125 to over $200 per month, we have been able to cost out a child's monthly fees at roughly $45. We have secured a beautiful space in downtown Oakland for the next five years and the doors have just opened as of December 14th for both kids and adults to begin training. This idea has become a reality with hard work and love. Now we need your help to make it a success.#jointhefightWith your help, how many lives we can change for the better?Twitter & Instagram - @guardiangym www.guardiangym.org-Joel & Ben

story:
CARE FOR THE CHILDREN AND YOU WILL HELP A LIFE, A COMMUNITY, A REGION, THE WORLD!

Our Vision

Every child matters! Help them in an active way until they get a feel for who and how they are, of the values and treasures that lie within them, of the infinite possibilities that surround them; show them that together is the healthier and wiser way to move forward in life. By succeeding in doing so, you might succeed in improving a live and helping a community, a village, a city, a region, a country, the world!

Our Mission

We want to help Romanian Children from poor rural areas, who are not given the chance, neither by the society, nor by their surroundings, to grow and develop as other more fortunate children their age.  We want to help them long enough so that to have a lasting impact on their lives. 

We intend to take regular trips to Romania and work with the children for one week at a time, involve them in activities that that bring them joy and help them discover themselves and their surroundings, and grow into independent and self-sufficient individuals. 

We further hope that, inspired by our example, more people and organizations will take similar actions. 

Our First Activity

A first activity will take place during the last week of April, in collaboration with a Romanian organization, Tasuleasa Social. 30 children from very poor families, some who cannot afford to go to school, and us, will be housed at Tasuleasa's campus for the entire week.  There we will play together, learn about nature together, take walks and trips together, learn a sport, read stories together, learn to become like brothers and sisters to one another.  

Your support

Providing housing, food, and access to facilities for one child will cost 35 euro/day, which for 30 children means over 5500 euros. Your much appreciated support would help us cover part of these expenses. The rest we will be paying ourselves. 

Contact

http://www.ralucaciulei.com/contact.html

REFERENCES

"Interviewing Raluca Ciulei - How active involvement brings change"

http://casa-romanilor.ch/interviewing-raluca-ciulei-how-active-involvement-brings-change-4213

Saturday afternoon, in a coffee shop in Zürich, a few enthusiasts were heavily debating upon a project. This is how I found Raluca Ciulei, a self-driven, passionate and visionary person, from whom we all could learn something and to whose projects we could be a part of.

House of Romanians in Switzerland (C.R.): We’ve been promoting your initiative to support unprivileged children through a non-formal education project. Now we are curious to find out more about you.
Raluca Ciulei: I am currently working as a quantitative analyst for an energy company in Bern, after having lived in different parts of the world. At the age of 16, I moved to Germany due to my professional tennis career, then at the age of 19 I had the chance to study at an Ivy League university, where I was awarded a leadership scholarship. This was followed by 2 years on the professional tennis tour, after which I arrived in Switzerland, where I studied Mathematics at ETH Zürich and where I am currently living.

There is something that comes from within and that has always been there- a drive, a feeling, a vision to bring change where it is needed.

C.R.: You lived less than 18 years in Romania- considerably less than most of the Romanians in Switzerland, who moved here only later, to work or to study. What drives you to have such an initiative for your home country?
R.C.: There is something that comes from within and that has always been there- a drive, a feeling, a vision to bring change where it is needed. I believe that in Romania, as in any other society or community, if we care for the children, we can bring change.  I want to start with the unprivileged children, with whom the fate was less giving.

C.R.: Have you done any entrepreneurial activity before? Starting a project of this magnitude from scratch requires a certain courage and ambition, traits that not any student from a highly ranked university, nor any performer has.
R.C.: No, I have never done anything similar before. However, everything I have achieved so far, I did on my own, without anybody’s help, in a perpetual learning by doing. Everything came from within, and everything I wanted and I felt like doing, I did. I have always felt that I will implement such a project one day!

C.R.: Congratulations! Now tell us more about the project and about your vision.
R.C.: As I have already mentioned, I believe that caring for a child will not only improve his life but also the life of his community. I also believe in active involvement from our side, rather than a passive one.
I further hope that others will follow our example.

C.R.: It is a complex project on informal education. Could you give us more details?
R.C.: At this stage of the project, the program is not thoroughly defined. The activities that will take place shall bring joy to the children, shall help them discover themselves and learn valuable lessons for their lives.  We will encourage learning by doing and look to facilitate as many experiences for the children as possible. We further believe in leading by example, hence we are aware that the children will learn from our ways of treating ourselves and the children, from the way we interact with each other, from the way we enjoy what we do.
They will be the ones to decide what they would like to do and learn and when. We will only be there to encourage them to discover things by themselves and help each other.
Through playing, sports, social interaction, trips, these children will start discovering themselves, their surrounding and the richness that lies within them. They will also learn to help and support each other and to care for each other, for the environment and for their community.

The education in too many places today has too many imposed topics that do not encourage the curiosity the children have.

C.R.: How did you have the idea to implement informal education in such a project?
R.C.: My experience at elite universities, in the jobs I’ve had and with the people I’ve interacted with showed me that nowadays education and society impose too many restrictions, rules and beliefs upon us about what we should and should not do. These rules, often combined with subtle forms of punishment, shut down our creativity, courage, enthusiasm, deprive us of our freedom, transform us into competitors and slaves of work, until we reach the gates of hell and realize that the road was more than foreign to us.  My very own experience sits behind my idea. In order to witness alternative education at work, I attended classes at Steiner/Waldorf School (schools based on autonomous learning) and seminars on Natural Learning as encountered in the LAIS schools for example, where children are encouraged to discover everything by themselves, at their own pace, and to teach each other. The education in too many places today has too many imposed topics that do not encourage the curiosity the children have. Education, as we often experience it, offers answers, imposes solving algorithms, it is based on too much theory and too little practice - in contrast, this new form allows the children to become more self-confident, to become autonomous by answering their own questions by themselves with enthusiasm, courage, creativity and curiosity. Children should not be interrupted; we have to stop clipping their wings. The pedagogues have only the role to observe and guide them, eventually answering them with another question, when they hit a dead-end. 

C.R.: Do you believe that such an approach could be successful in Romania because it contrasts very well the methods that have already been applied, or even compensates the lack of professionalism at some levels in the educational system?
R.C.: I believe in the effectiveness of informal education regardless of the society where it is being applied.
In western Europe, as well as in Romania, the idea of success has to be redefined: we cannot continuously repeat to our children that if and only if they become, let’s say, doctors, they will be someone. As long as you are doing what you are passionate about and you keep alive the desire to explore, you are successful. Maybe this is the way towards a world with less depression and with fewer people forced to follow a certain career trajectory, one where the individual freedom is truly encouraged.

All they have is the richness within and the joy to have each other.

C.R.: Why is the program then applied in rural poor areas?
R.C.: Children here have the least support, they are almost forgotten by the society and considered only part of some statistics, not to say, they barely get to see anything from this big world. All they have is the richness within and the joy to have each other. We want to help them discover exactly these two things, to become more confident and self-sufficient, and to help one another.

C.R.: How could people that are interested in the project contribute at this point?
R.C.: Since it is the first time we organize such an event, we are counting on the help of a Romanian organization, Tasuleasa Social, that will help us with accommodation, food, their pedagogical forest and other resources that they might have. All these will cost us 35 euro per day per child. I will personally go to Tasuleasa next week, to meet the people there, see their facilities and clarify the program for the 30 children we will be taking care of. Since the costs will be over 5500 euro, from which I myself paid 1500 euro and other wonderful friends donated about 600 euros, 3400 euro are still needed. Every contribution and expense is being recorded, and I will provide receipts for the expenses.
Donations of toys or cloths are very welcome too. Any contact of a possible sponsor would be greatly appreciated.

More about the project and Raluca can be found here on the website:
http://www.ralucaciulei.com/projects.html


Donations can be made directly here
https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/active-support-of-underprivileged-chi...


And don’t hesitate to contact her directly for any questions
http://www.ralucaciulei.com/contact.html

story:
Bio_Nick

Bio_Nick is a 3D Printed prosthetic hand which is actuated using signals from foot and send them to the actuators and it results in the motion of the hand and the complete hand cost for 100USD.

So, I have design prosthesis that can be accessible to everyone around the world to people with limited financial resources and for people with physical disabilities living in rural area.

 

A personal note

I want to thank you from my bottom of heart for giving your precious time to learn more about my project. The topic of disability is not just a matter of talk it's a very serious issue that we need to solve not by words but by action because in 4 children near you one is with some kind of disability

The reason why I'm so interested in helping out with prosthetics in developing countries is that during my research I had the chance to meet a small girl personally

 

she was around 5 years old living without any hand and at that time I wondered what could have led her to have this life that she is having and as I researched more on this topic I learned that their lack of health care, safety and financial resources.

So, with all your support one day I hope to go back to not only this girl  but to many other children's and people who are living such a life and help them to get the proper prosthetic care they deserve

 

 

A few statistics about prosthetic in developing nations

The real condition in developing countries:

  • I in every 5 children suffer from amputation.
  • Every year 1 out of 1500 children are born without hand or fingers.
  • 80% of all amputees are actually in developing nations.
  • And less than 3% of them have the access to  prosthetic care
  • Because children grow quickly there are few prosthetic devices available for them which cost thousands of dollars and many families can not afford them.

where will your money go?

 

Your donation will help me to provide the prosthetic hand Bio_Nick for free to children's and other people who can not afford the prosthetic device. 

The first initiative will be to provide about 10 to 20 hands to children's and to people with other age and from their experiences, we will  make  it more comfortable , easy to use and aesthetic . Second, we will start a  social media campaign to make people more aware of this prosthetic care service.

Some of the expenses include:

▪  Production cost

▪  Equipment cost

▪  Travel costs

▪  Location fees

▪   Crew meals

▪  Stipends for interns

▪  Website hosting

▪  Printing and T-shirts

▪  Social media marketing.
 

Other Ways You Can Help

First and foremost, we welcome your donation! That will help us to provide a proper prosthetic care.

Second, you can help us by spreading the word about Bio_NIck by sharing  this link on your favorite online platforms (Facebook, Twitter, G+, etc.) or via email to your network. Your engagement will help us to help others.

The Funds that will be raised will be used to designed a  free prosthetic arm for an amputee.

story:
Short Summary

The "Little League World Series" of Youth Basketball does not exist...until NOW.

The event is happening with 10 of the best teams (8th graders - Incoming Freshman) converging in San Diego this weekend for a world class intimate experience they will never forget.  Your pledge will help raise the experience level even more, and help us get to the next evolution, placing this on ESPN and being worldwide by next year.

About Me

Mr. Hershman brings over 12 years of business, sales, sports marketing, and social media branding experience.

Mr. Hershman was a co-founder of Top Gun Basketball that started 7 years ago and it one of the top Academy’s in the United States. 

He also was involved in starting Indivisible Hoops and with the experience in business quickly propelled it to the forefront of the basketball community in less than a year. 

Currently, Brian helps run Top Gun Basketball Academy, Indivisible Hoops, and a newly funded company: relEVENT

Mr. Hershman has a unique insight and experience managing challenges faced by start-ups, growing companies and brands.

He graduated from University of Arizona with a degree in Education and holds an MBA from Point Loma Nazarene.

Risks & Challenges

We can deliver everything promised because the event is already set up.  The only risk and challenge we can foresee is the status of what the bigger kickstarter investors will have regarding their share values of the company.

story:
Most students start their first day of kindergarten two years behind the expected educational benchmarks.   Two years behind from day one!  This gap only widens as students progress through the education system.  (Research references for these statistics can be found at the bottom our story!) 

There is an easy fix to this staggering reality. Reading to infants and toddlers, even when they cannot yet read themselves, puts them on track for starting kindergarten right at the starting line, instead of losing before the race has even begun.   

Our goal is to create a monthly subscription box that contains well-written children's books on topics that are chosen to help students think, learn, and engage with their world.  Our book choices are centered around themes of social justice, equality, education, and fun! 

One of the biggest obstacles stopping children from starting kindergarten prepared is access to quality books, and parents who are unsure of how best to support their children's reading. Our project aims to help parents overcome this obstacle and to help students who do not have access to books. 

We believe that all students, no matter their background, deserve the opportunity to start school just as prepared as their peers. As teachers ourselves, we also know that funds for supplies for books in the classroom can be hard to come by, and often come out of the teacher's own pockets.  This is something we want to help remedy! 

For each box purchased, we will donate a book to a local school or early childhood literacy-related non-profit.  Subscribers can choose between our two home cities of Chicago or Boston for where they would like their donated book to be delivered.  We will personally deliver books to the chosen local public schools each month. 

As two teachers with 14 years of educating between us, we have a huge passion for reading and literature.  As former students attending the same college and undertaking the same Master's program in Literacy and Education, we grew our passion for educational and entertaining children's books and have worked hard to incorporate them into our teaching practices. 

Our book choices for this project have been hand-picked and reviewed by a school librarian and published Junior Library Guild children's reviewer, a professor of children's literature at the University of Illinois, and two educators with Master's degrees in literacy and designations as literacy specialists.  

Our goal is to put quality literature into the hands of children everywhere and to provide parents with the tools they need to help their readers become lifelong learners. 

Each box will include: 

Three hand-picked books that deal with the any of the themes of social justice, equality, activism, kindness, empathy, and/or self-esteem

One fun sticker to promote reading (stickers are the best)

One small educational game (because toys are fun!)

Three book labels to personalize your books

One literacy pamphlet with activities/ directions for reading and literacy information for parents to support their children's reading growth with research-backed practices

Example book titles include: 

Ada Twist Scientist

The Boy Who Harnessed the Wind

Separate is Never Equal

Firebird: Misty Copeland

Free as a Bird: The Story of Malala

Click Clack Moo: Cows that Type 

Ada's Violin

And many more! 

The funds from this Kickstarter will be used for the following business supplies: 

- Books!  (this is the biggest, but most important cost!)

-packaging and shipping materials

-website costs

-storage space

-pamphlet printing costs

-advertising costs

- goodies included in each box

Research driving our mission (We love research!) 

(taken from Ferst Foundation for Childhood Literacy)

Reading aloud to young children is not only one of the best activities to stimulate language and cognitive skills; it also builds motivation, curiosity, and memory. Bardige, B. Talk to Me, Baby!(2009), Paul H Brookes Pub Co.

Experts are nearly unanimous in stating that babies should routinely experience shared books as soon as they experience shared talking, that is, during the first weeks and months of life. Butler, D. (1998). Babies need books. Portsmouth, NH: Heinemann.

Children growing up in homes with at least 20 books get 3 years more schooling than children from bookless homes, independent of their parents’ education, occupation, and class. Evans, M. D., Kelley, J., Sikora, J., & Treiman, D. J. (2010). Family scholarly culture and educational success: Books and schooling in 27 nations. Research in Social Stratification and Mobility, 28(2), 171-197.

Given the course of brain development, it is not surprising that young children who are exposed to certain early language and literacy experiences usually prove to be good readers later. Just as a child develops language skills long before being able to speak, the child also develops literacy skills long before being able to read. National Research Council. (1998). Preventing Reading Difficulties in Young Children. Washington, D.C.: National Academy Press.  

Given the course of brain development, it is not surprising that young children who are exposed to certain early language and literacy experiences usually prove to be good readers later. Just as a child develops language skills long before being able to speak, the child also develops literacy skills long before being able to read. National Research Council. (1998). Preventing Reading Difficulties in Young Children. Washington, D.C.: National Academy Press.

In the first three years, infants and toddlers begin acquiring the first of thousands of words they will use throughout their lives. Simultaneously, children are learning the rules of grammar as well as absorbing the social conventions that exist around communication in their community. Im, J., Osborn, C., Sánchez, S. and Thorp, E. (in press). Cradling Literacy: Building Teachers’ Skills to Nurture Early Language and Literacy Birth to Five. Washington, DC: ZERO TO THREE.

While good early experiences help the brain develop well, poor experiences can literally cause a genetically normal child to have a lower I.Q. Scientific evidence shows that maltreated children who receive little stimulation – children who are exposed to fewer colors, less touch, little interaction with adults, fewer sights and sounds, and less language – actually have smaller brains. De Bellis, M.D., Keshaven, M.S., Clark,D.B., Caseey, B.J., Giedd, J.B., Boring,A.M., Frustaci, K., & Ryan, N.D. (1999).Developmental traumatology.Part 2: Brain development. BiologicalPsychiatry, 45, 1271-1284.

More information about the absolute necessity of early childhood literacy can be found on the following sites: 

https://www.ferstfoundation.org/resources/fifty...

https://www.bookspring.org/literacy-statistics/
story_txt:
Most students start their first day of kindergarten two years behind the expected educational benchmarks.   Two years behind from day one!  This gap only widens as students progress through the education system.  (Research references for these statistics can be found at the bottom our story!) 
There is an easy fix to this staggering reality. Reading to infants and toddlers, even when they cannot yet read themselves, puts them on track for starting kindergarten right at the starting line, instead of losing before the race has even begun.   
Our goal is to create a monthly subscription box that contains well-written children's books on topics that are chosen to help students think, learn, and engage with their world.  Our book choices are centered around themes of social justice, equality, education, and fun! 
One of the biggest obstacles stopping children from starting kindergarten prepared is access to quality books, and parents who are unsure of how best to support their children's reading. Our project aims to help parents overcome this obstacle and to help students who do not have access to books. 
We believe that all students, no matter their background, deserve the opportunity to start school just as prepared as their peers. As teachers ourselves, we also know that funds for supplies for books in the classroom can be hard to come by, and often come out of the teacher's own pockets.  This is something we want to help remedy! 
For each box purchased, we will donate a book to a local school or early childhood literacy-related non-profit.  Subscribers can choose between our two home cities of Chicago or Boston for where they would like their donated book to be delivered.  We will personally deliver books to the chosen local public schools each month. 
As two teachers with 14 years of educating between us, we have a huge passion for reading and literature.  As former students attending the same college and undertaking the same Master's program in Literacy and Education, we grew our passion for educational and entertaining children's books and have worked hard to incorporate them into our teaching practices. 
Our book choices for this project have been hand-picked and reviewed by a school librarian and published Junior Library Guild children's reviewer, a professor of children's literature at the University of Illinois, and two educators with Master's degrees in literacy and designations as literacy specialists.  
Our goal is to put quality literature into the hands of children everywhere and to provide parents with the tools they need to help their readers become lifelong learners. 
Each box will include: 
Three hand-picked books that deal with the any of the themes of social justice, equality, activism, kindness, empathy, and/or self-esteem
One fun sticker to promote reading (stickers are the best)
One small educational game (because toys are fun!)
Three book labels to personalize your books
One literacy pamphlet with activities/ directions for reading and literacy information for parents to support their children's reading growth with research-backed practices
Example book titles include: 
Ada Twist Scientist
The Boy Who Harnessed the Wind
Separate is Never Equal
Firebird: Misty Copeland
Free as a Bird: The Story of Malala
Click Clack Moo: Cows that Type 
Ada's Violin
And many more!

- Books!  (this is the biggest, but most important cost!)
-packaging and shipping materials
-website costs
-storage space
-pamphlet printing costs
-advertising costs
- goodies included in each box

story:
Science is for everyone.

We want students all across the country to believe that, and we need your help to make it happen! We are seeing a shift in our society to encourage more interest in STEM (science, technology, engineering, math) and with reason. 

Science  promotes creativity, confidence, critical thinking skills, and independent thought. 

But science can be intimidating if presented poorly, both in and out of the classroom. In fact, females are less likely to pursue interests in STEM after high school, in part due to the lack of positive role models, and this lack of representation affects students of color even more.  

We're ready to address these issues nationwide by mixing science with its natural counterpart- the arts.

After all, everyone knows that science and the arts go hand-in-hand!

Jargie the Science Girl!  is a live, interactive children's show that combines the magic of theatre with the world of science. Geared at grades K-5, Jargie and her penguin lab assistant Benjamin take the audience on a scientific adventure that empowers everyone to think critically and creatively about the world around them.  We've been touring locally to schools in Southern California since 2017 and we are ready to take this wonderful program to theaters across the United States! Here is a sneak peek of our national version:

 

What we've accomplished so far...

Jargie the Science Girl! was first created by Jocelyn Argueta and Steve Cisneros in 2016 (learn more about the creative team below). Since its first show in January of 2017, there has been a steady, and increasing, interest in the performance and in our mission to promote science through arts education.  Here are a few highlights of the last two years. 

-Performed for nearly 2,500 students at 26 locations, which include schools, malls, after-school programs, youth groups
-Gained representation by Segerstrom Center for the Arts in Orange County
-Met and talked to Broadway producers at the Commercial Theatre Institute in New York
-Attended the California Activities Director Association
-Pitched Jargie to producers from all around the country at the Western Arts Alliance 2018
-Exhibited at the California Science Teachers Association Conference in 2016 and 2018
-Booked four performances at the Smithsonian Institute's Discovery Theater in Washington D.C. for March 2019
-Booked and sold out two performances at the Edmonds Center for the Arts in Washington state for April 2019
-Currently talking to other theater venues across the country

What we need for 2019 and the future:

We are so proud of what our “little” show has become and especially of how many students have seen us and said “Science is so awesome! I want to do it too.” Two years ago, this was just an idea on a piece of paper and we used every resource available to us to get it in front of as many curious minds as possible. Now we need your help to multiply that number!

Here is how we plan on using the funds raised. Every dollar counts and your gift is tax deductible to the fullest extent of the law.

Props and Materials $2,200 

Bright colorful props bring the show to life! Due to the zaniness in the performance, the props get dropped a lot, so it is important for us to maintain and replace them as necessary. 

Multimedia $1,100

One of the most unique parts of the show is the in-show multimedia and projections. They create a full theatrical spectacle that captivates the attention of our young audience.

Marketing Materials $4,400

We want to put our best beaker forward with high quality prints and promotional videos.

Staffing $4,400

It takes a village to put on a one-penguin show! Stage managers, prop masters, set designers, and more! Every individual behind the scenes is essential to our process.

Public Relations $5,500

Jargie is a female, Hispanic scientist. She is a unique role model that needs to be seen in mainstream media, beyond theatre. Representation matters and we need a strong Public Relations team to help young minds everywhere be able to see themselves in STEM roles.

Conferences $16,500

Just like trade shows are needed for physical products, we need to be at conferences to sell this show and get the attention of more theater venues across the country. Just to name a few of the conferences we need to attend: Western Arts Alliance, Arts Midwest, International Performing Arts for Youth, Association of Performing Arts Professionals

Travel/Accommodations $4,400

We have to go where producers are and can see our show; unfortunately that is not always in Southern California.

Other ways to help

Share, share, share! Tell your friends, family, co-workers, neighbors, everyone about our goal and help us spread the word. We really depend on your help. 

Link to this page: https://igg.me/at/JargieNational 
Facebook: www.facebook.com/Jargiethesciencegirl 

Meet the team that makes it all happen

Phantom Projects Theatre Group enters their 21st year of producing and presenting live theatrical events geared towards children and teens, through a combination of literature-based works, message-based dramas, and family entertainment. For the past 18 years, the troupe has been a resident group at the 1,300-seat La Mirada Theatre for the Performing Arts where they present a 6-show season. Each year, they also travel to nearly 50 Southern California schools with shows about bullying, racism, prejudice and tolerance.

Jocelyn Argueta (Co-Creator, Writer, Performer) is a quirky biochemist eager to share her love for science, theatre, oxidative stress-induced mitochondrial dysfunction, and the color pink. She received her Bachelor’s degree in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology from the University of California, Irvine and has taken an active role in Neurobiology research focusing on neurodegeneration and aging diseases. Her work in Alzheimer’s disease and Down syndrome cell characterization was recently published in the Journal of Alzheimer’s Disease. She worked in the private sector, researching allergy diagnostics, with a patent pending in chemistry customization, after which she discovered her passion for arts education as a K-8 science instructor at a private academy.

Steve Cisneros (Co-Creator, Director, Founder of Phantom Projects) created Phantom Projects Theatre Group in 1997 at the age of 17, out of his parents’ 2-car garage. Overseeing the daily operations for the past 21 years, the troupe has been featured by and written about in Forbes, CBS, NBC, ABC, FOX, Washington Post, LA Times, and in publications from nearly 40 states around the United States. With a background in the performing arts, Cisneros has worked for Nederlander, South Coast Repertory, McCoy Rigby Entertainment, La Mirada Theatre and many more. He’s directed over 50 productions and produced over 100. In 2017, for his work in using theatre as a teaching tool for at-risk youth, Cisneros was recognized with the Ambassador of Peace Award from the Orange County Violence Prevention Coalition. Other honorees included a Judge, and a police officer, proving the power of theatre and the impact on young minds.

 

Thank you for your support, scientists! Remember to always Stay Curious!

story:
#GivingTuesday - TOTH Scholarship Fund*!

TOTH provides an early learning Montessori experience  striving to instill independence, confidence, and creativity in 1-6 years olds impacting them for a lifetime.  Find out more about TOTH, Montessori and our scholarship program by watching this video.

THE IMPACT:
Harvard University’s Center on the Developing Child has found that early childhood experiences, especially between 0–3 years, actually alter gene expression, shape brain architecture, and affect long-term development.  According to the Nobel  Prize-winning University of Chicago Economics Professor James Heckman:

•  “Early learning confers value on acquired skills, which leads to self-reinforcing motivation to learn more."

•  “Early mastery of a range of cognitive, social, and emotional competencies makes learning at later ages more efficient and therefore easier and more likely to continue.”

•  “Intervening at an early enough age can actually raise the IQ of the participants.”

MAKE SOME NOISE!
Use Indiegogo’s share tools on the left of this page to invite others to support this cause!

If you, your business, or your family would like to learn more about our scholarship, contact Joy Wilder.

​Special thanks go to the Capitol Hill Community Foundation for awarding us grants over multiple years.  Also, Steve Leroy and Libby Quaid for contributing Music Together Classes directly benefitting the scholarship.  Finally, to all of our parents and friends of TOTH for their generous support!

*TOTH is a social enterprise dedicated to serving families from diverse socio-economic backgrounds.  As a social enterprise, all contributions are not tax-deductible.

story:
This Holiday Season Invest in Peace and Innovation 

We are a group of teachers who saw that our current education system was broken. Our kids were exhausted and stressed and our peers were leaving the classroom in droves. We knew we could do better. 

All children deserve the chance to negotiate a life rich with choices. Yet for too many external factors trigger a semi-permanent state of fight or flight that renders them unable to focus on anything else. In addition to academic skills taught in schools, students need to develop skills early on in life to help them process and regulate complex emotions and manage persistent stress.

Headstand was founded to address these complex issues.  

When you meditate you are building character as you learn . . . It feels like I am gaining unimaginable power inside me. I feel stronger.

— Seventh Grade Student, KIPP Summit Academy 

This campaign helps us imagine the future of K-12 education with two innovation labs in the San Francisco Bay Area. These two schools will receive a full-time, dedicated teacher on site to build yoga, mindfulness, and meditation into the everyday experience of the students on campus. Students need and deserve a system that prioritizes compassion and self-knowledge as much as test scores.   

A group of scientists at Harvard discovered that in just eight weeks, mindfulness meditation decreases grey dense matter in the amygdala, a region of the brain associated with stress and anxiety.  

When you invest in our Headstand mindfulness and yoga lab, you're creating more peaceful, compassionate and mindful citizens. 

Why Should I Become a Headstand Peacemaker?

Our world—now more than ever—needs more peacemakers. By donating and becoming a Headstand Peacemaker, you’re empowering our future leaders to be calm, focused, and self-aware.

If you are a teacher, a parent, a school leader, a manager, a yogi, a mindfulness skeptic, or just someone who believes in the importance of educating our kids to be agents of peace, join us.

Joining our Giving Tuesday kick-off campaign and become a Headstand Peacemaker. If we reach our goal, we succeed in establishing the foundation of mindfulness and yoga education as a national model for groundbreaking K-12 curriculum.

  • We need $50,000 to fund our Headstand innovation labs with full-time, dedicated mindfulness and yoga teachers in the classroom. 
  • Support us for a chance to win a private yoga class with gourmet goodies in San Francisco, CA 
  • Support us for chance to visit our innovation Headstand labs and take a yoga + meditation class with our kids 
  • Support us for a the opportunity to participate in a day-long wellness retreat at Google HQ in Mountain View, CA

Current participating Headstand schools report:
                        
60% drop in school suspensions
79% students report significantly less perceived stress
84% students report frequent use of stress reduction techniques
100% surveyed staff highly recommend Headstand   

Headstand has been features on CBS National news, The Atlantic and several other media outlets. 

The Mindfulness Challenge 

Kids and teachers are bombarded with information and stress with the pressures of academic achievement, an ever evolving technological world and a society which all too often values business over interpersonal connection.  

If we know mindfulness meditation is proven to positively change the brain in MRI imaging, why aren't we teaching it in school?   

The simple truth is, most educators and administrators don't believe there is enough time in the day to fit in mindfulness meditation and yoga techniques and we don't blame them, we've been there. As former educators ourselves, we want to fix this problem. We know immersing ourselves deeply into school culture to build an innovative mindfulness and yoga lab works.  

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Please get the word out and share our campaign
  • Spread the word! Follow Headstand on Facebook and Instagram
  • Join our day-long Summit at the Google HQ campus in Mountain View on 1/27/18
  • Interested in volunteering? Email shyla@headstand.org
  • Keep an eye out for our donation-based yoga classes happening in San Francisco in the coming months
  • Use the indiegogo share tools to spread the word and let others know they can be a part of the change to build a more mindful, peaceful future
